Posted: December 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								First of all, your search for the ultimate car game/simulator ends RIGHT HERE and RIGHT NOW. I'm serious. No other simulator in history has ever been as realistic as BeamNG.drive. In fact, once this sim gets popular, it could even be used in driving schools! The cars handle, perform, and DEform EXACTLY like their real life counterparts. Behind each car is a revolutionary system of nodes and beams that calculates the deformation of the car's body at 2000 times a second! Not only that, but the windows crack and shatter, and pretty much every part from the headlights to the tailpipes to the fenders to the engine can break off like they would in real life.This is a long, in-depth review, to give you the best idea of what this is.This is an awesome simulator! You can do anything you want with cars, trucks, boats, planes, and drive/fly them as well as smash them, crash them, and drop boulders on them (Yes, I'm not kidding). If you want you can put that 3 foot high spoiler on your 1990 Honda! The base game comes with 13 worlds (aka terrains) to explore, and they range from 1 square kilometer to 4 square kilometers. The developers do, however make them seem much bigger despite their real size. There is also an infinite grid map which is completely flat and empty and the ground is nothing more than a grid. In addition, there are maps created by the community that can be as big as ~350 square kilometers. Once BeamNG's engine gets optimized to the point we can have open world maps, we will start seeing even larger maps.Here are the vehicles included with BeamNG.Also in the base game are 20 fictional vehicles (as of last review update) based off of real-life vehicles, which are FULLY customizable. In addition to in-depth customization, you also get about 10 preset configurations (trims) for every car. You can choose the one you like the most and then add/remove/change the parts on that trim to make it JUST the way you want. Here is the vehicle list:http://wiki.beamng.com/Official_Content#VehiclesAnyway, enough about the content. Let's get into the gameplay and physics.Although for now there is no Career mode, this simulator is still very fun to play. There are scenarios, and they are usually coordinated time trials on a specific course on a specific terrain. Sometimes it is just for fun, like jumping a van off a ramp and landing unscathed. And the physics, oh they will not get any better than this. BeamNG is the most realistic and detailed vehicle simulator to date. It simulates the behavior of vehicles from the glass breaking to the hubcaps falling off. BeamNG uses a unique system for ultra-realistic vehicle behavior that yields a unique gaming experience each time. It uses beams (BEAMng) and nodes to simulate each and every part independently. The nodes connect all of the thousands of beams together, and the beams can deform, bend, and break. There are no predefined damage models. The node and beam system calculates the damage on any one section of the car. For example, if you slide past a wall in a Need For Speed game, with the front facing it slightly more than the back, the windows will probably shatter and then there will be paint scratches on random places of the car. Let's slide past that same wall in BeamNG. The mirror fell off and there is a dent in the front bumper EXACTLY where the car contacted the wall. Also a hubcap most likely fell off if the car had plastic rims.If all that isn't enough, there is a big community on the BeamNG forums cranking out mods frequently. There are about 50 extra vehicles for download at the time of this writing and well over 75 terrains. About the devs, they're on it with a big update at least every month. In just about a year we have gotten from version 0.4 all the way to 0.6.And, finally, let's talk customization. Let's take the D-15 for example. For this single vehicle, you can customize the paint job, the tow hitch, the type of engine (I6 or V8), supercharger, lights, color, bumper type and color, suspension, body, and even the light bar to name a few. So the bottom line is, this game offers more customization options than any other driving game currently on the market.I hope this review was helpful to any new BeamNG players. Enjoy this wonderful game!

content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
Early Access Review
Introduction BeamNG.drive is a realistic soft-body physics simulator developed by BeamNG. BeamNG.drive not only lets you drive realistic cars, it also lets you crash them into each other! While the racing may not appeal to those who don’t use a wheel, the game’s awesome physics can be easily enjoyed using a gamepad or even a keyboard. It’s worth mentioning I’m in the camp of mainly crashing things into each other so I won’t focus so much on anything more heavily related to racing.While I’ve only recently received the game I have been following its progress for around a year and it has received regular updates during that time. Obviously it’s still not a finished product but what’s already in the game is good and if the devs continue working on the game it’s only going to get better.Full Disclosure: A review copy was provided by the developer.Presentation As you’d expect from a realistic simulator, it’s a good looking game. Of course it’s not to the point of being photo-realistic but everything looks good enough in the game to make it feel about as real as a simulator can be. The UI and menus are absolutely spot on for the game, the speedometer is usually the only visible UI element and it’s only visible when you’re using the third person camera, it’s out of the way otherwise which certainly helps your driving if you’re just smashing things into each other. The menus are simple and easy to use and even when you’re using the menu you can still see most of the screen (which is good because you’ll occasionally want to be editing your option while playing the game, for example if you want to increase gravity while you’re mid-air to utterly obliterate your car).Gameplay BeamNG.drive’s two (current) game modes are Scenarios and Free Roam with a Career mode coming soon. The Scenario game mode features pre-made scenarios from the developers themselves as well as any user made scenarios that you download from the BeamNG website. Generally these scenarios are either races or car tests but some of them are a little more exciting (not to say the others aren’t fun) such as scenarios where you drive a police car and you have to stop a speeding vehicle. The Free Roam mode is pretty much self-explanatory, you can choose one of the game’s eleven maps with any of the game’s thirteen vehicles. You can also use other in-game objects here too like a giant hamster wheel or a canon. Free Roam is where you’ll be making your own scenarios if you’re so inclined but as far as I can tell you need the Scenario editing mod from the website to do this. But if you don’t want to make your own scenarios it can be a lot of fun to just drive your car around one of the Island maps or smash it into things in the gridmap full of ramps and other fun things. Realism Realism is of course the most important part of a simulation game and, as far as I can tell, BeamNG.drive is pretty realistic. Now it is worth mentioning that I don’t drive and I’ve never seen a real car crash but I reckon I’ve got enough experience as a passenger and as someone who has a decent knowledge of physics to comment on this aspect of the game. Of course it’s hard to tell when playing with a gamepad rather than a wheel but vehicle handling seems pretty solid. As far as I know there’s no traction control for the vehicles in the game so things do get a little bit skiddy from time to time but the cars all feel pretty weighty (apart from the three wheel Pigeon of course). The soft body physics are out of this world good, I don’t think I’ve come across a game with better. Obviously slamming things into each other looks good but it’s when you misjudge a corner and go head on into a tree that you really see just how powerful the engine is.


Well that's one way to stop a car 
A Screenshot of BeamNG.drive
By: Kemo




Miscellaneous When in Free Roam you have control over environmental variables such as time of day and gravity and in both Free Roam and Scenarios you’re able to slow down time up to 100x.All thirteen vehicles have several different pre-made configurations but you can customize the cars with parts and paint jobs as well as then save whatever you make to be used in future.The game ran really well for me despite the fact that I have a pretty weak GPU.There’s not a huge amount of ‘defined’ content right now so if you’re not the kind of person who can make their own fun in a sandbox game then you may wish to hit the follow button instead of buying the game for the time being. Just to be clear, there’s probably a good few hours of scenarios The engine sounds didn’t sound too realistic to me but that may just be from a lack of car knowledge rather than the sounds being unrealistic. It turns out that these sound effects are simply placeholders for the time being. The crashing sound effects are reasonably good but if you’re hitting things for a prolonged period of time it seems the sound effects are only audible from time to time rather than every time there’s a collision.While the vehicles in the game aren’t ‘real’ makes and models they are all based on real vehicles.Verdict Worth Purchasing.  (If you like Sandbox physics games)BeamNG.drive may be lacking in 'defined' content but it more than makes up for it with its incredibly realistic soft body physics and good graphics. If you want a realistic driving sim or you just want to crash things into each other then chances are you’ll enjoy this game!No drama, Just Reviews.El K.

Posted: October 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								A review is nothing if it isn't helpful, so let's get down to brass tacks. At the moment, you should know BeamNG is not a game.  It's at best a sandbox title with most of the necessary content missing.  Its far better to say at the moment that its a game engine looking for a game.  But what a game engine ...The content, as it stands, offers you the chance to drive round a handful of locations.  Thanks to Johnny3600 who points out that this game uses Torque3D as an engine, not the CryEngine as I first thought (though the backgrounds are very Far Cry - think tropical, vegetation, poorish roads), but critically are quite large and varied.  So you can expect well-made tarmacked roads to ring islands, with grotty little dirt tracks in the centre often leading to ledges, mountains etc.  The vehicles are mostly regular cars (I believe generic models), including pickups and a Rig.  Don't expect forumula 1 cars, this is a far more everyday selection of vehicles.So far it all sounds uninspiring.  What makes it so good?  Well, the physics engine effectively makes it a crash simulator.  Every piece of each car is detailed to give it form, bendableness, weight and mass, etc.  When assembled they work as a real car would, but when you come into contact with something they all crush, get displaced and generally smash up most convincingly.  On its own its not enough to make a car game, but when its combined with a very satisfying feeling of driving you have a potential monster hit.In a word, what we have here is the beauty of mathematics, cutting edge in all its glory, put to use to smash things up.  It's fantastic, rewarding, enormous fun to drive, and best of all utterly convincing.  I've crashed enough in this game to know that you don't want to fishtail and clip the rear of your car if you're going to crash in real life because the loss of control is horrendous (as in how a certain English ex-Princess met her fate).  You stand a far better chance of survival just going head on with an object despite the g-forces (with a seatbelt, of course.)  Trust me, the first time you crash a car in this game, the sense of emotional trauma in the silence that follows is palpable.So there it is.  A few cars, some nice locations, and nothing to do.  All dressed up and nowhere to go.  I'm not even sure that anyone knows exactly how it will all end up when it finally becomes a game.  There are experiments with car chases, and there's always the prospect of multiplayer, but frankly it doesn't lend itself to the usual genres of car games.  You just have to buy it on faith at the moment, but its still immensely enjoyable.Crazikyle points out that there are lots of MODs available right now and for many people this is a deal breaker.  I'm no expert on MODs, so by all means anyone who has some to recommend should add them to the bottom of the review in the comments section.  I want to make this review as helpful as possible, and if you folks can help do that by contributing suggestions then please go right ahead and do so.One more thought to leave you with: I've played some excellent racing games including iRacer, Project Cars, Assetto Corsa, etc.  None of them feel like you are driving an organic, real-world machine quite the way that BeamNG does.  The cars in BeamNG are made of assembled pieces, and the pieces shake and rattle and bounce under the torque and forces just like a real car.  Other developers  'pretend' their cars are real by suggesting movement and bounce, but only BeamNG has the sense that you have a real, honest-to-God vehicle glued to your throttle pedal.If that isn't enough to pique your interest, may I suggest a nice game of Scrabble?

When I played the game with my X-360 controller, I thought it was neat. The damage physics, the way the suspension moves, the way the body rolls with bumps is just amazing. This game has the best soft-body physics I've seen in any game. When I really fell in love with the game, as you can see in the above video, is when I hooked my Logitech G27 up to it. Wow! The off-road handling is fantastic with a wheel. In my mind, this game is the spiritual successor to the original 1nsane. Of course it doesn't have any of the game modes (it is in alpha) but I've never had this much fun driving off road in a game before. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes driving off-road, and has an FFB wheel laying around. You dont need a G27 to enjoy the game, even a $50 Driving Force Pro would work great with it.In addition to all the above, the game has a strong, and quickly growing mod community. Posted: January 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Perfect game for any car fan, regardless of age. There's not a whole lot of fancy graphics, no lens flares, relatively simple smoke/dust effects, most foliage (except trees) are made of flat textures (which are pretty well done, you can't really tell unless you stop and zoom right in on the grass, looks fine if you're driving even at low speeds), and the shaders aren't modified to give a 'cinematic look'. So this game isn't an astonishingly pretty game. But you know what, that's okay.Each vehicle is intricately modelled, down to the point where you can see each individual part of the engine. You can see the butterfly valves on your supercharged V8 muscle car, you can see the engine block move around in its mounts slightly as you rev the engine. The level of detail is insane. Hit a harsh bump that bottoms out your custom, lowered car? Be prepared to potentially have your entire exhaust system ripped out of your car. Hit a sharp kerb at high speed? Might wanna watch your tires, they can pop, giving your car an unnatural feel. The physical damage in this game is brutally realistic, as each car is not 'hard-coded' with performance stats, health points, etc. Each INDIVIDUAL PART of a car makes up it's whole performance, much like a real car. Pop your front-right tire, and your car will start veering slightly to the right. Fit sport tires, you might be able to handle a corner slightly faster. Lower your suspension, you'll reduce body rolls and keep all 4 tires on the road better, resulting in better grip.It goes on and on. The soft-body physics overall are brilliant, the cars crumple, wobble, and react exactly how you'd expect a car to react.Maps:The maps that come with the game are very nice, and quite varied.Gridmap: A testing map, with an assortment of jumps, surface types (from sand and dirt to mud and water), slalom cones, objects to crash into and a few high-speed race courses.Port: A small map set on a port, a perfect map for Gymkhana or drifting fans, with all kinds of shipping containers, warehouses, and a few ramps along with it. Industrial Site: A medium sized map set on a seaside industrial area, it features a RallyCross track with multiple configurations, an offroad racing track laced with thick mud that will bog down your average rally car, but take a big 4x4 and you'll plow straight on through, and a more traditional tarmac race course. The industrial area also features many warehouses like the Port map, and a nice little circuit that races around it, featuring a jump over a small inlet.East Coast USA: Set in the East Coast of the USA (As the nae suggests), it has a medium-sized town, along with fairly well maintained roads, that go from the coast to snaking through the forest. Lots of dirt trails through fields and woodlands for rallying around too.Jungle Rock Island: On a Tropical Island, this map has poorly-maintained roads that call for terrifying high-speed driving along the coastline of this island. It also has many offroad dirt trails that run through the forest, and can quite easily end up getting you lost! There's also a few little rally trails, and industrial areas, quarries, and a port. Probably my favourite map.Cliff: Spawns you in at the top of a cliff, the only way around is down the cliff. Fun little map for just throwing stuff of cliffs and watching it arrive at the bottom as a mangled mess. Not much to the map other than that, but still fun nonetheless.Hirochi Raceway: A race-focused map, this raceway is GP-styled, with very wide, smooth corners, along with fast straights and chicanes thrown in. This map also has a few forest routes, that can take you on a narrow road through some forests, so any mistakes can be fatal.So, quite a few maps, with lots of variety.ScenariosThe game has a wide variety of scenarios, too many to list here, that cover multiple fun aspects of the game.These can range from tutorials, to shakedowns of various cars, police chases, races, delivery challenges, even a 'hyper-miling' challenge where you have to cross Jungle Rock Island with very little gas left in your car. There's even a demolition derby scenario for people to 'party play'.Overall, I'd give this game a 8/10, I'd like to see networked multiplayer (something the BeamNG devs might implement if their engine can support it) and a campaign mode (which the devs have planned pretty much since day 1 of the project)Lots more potential, the modding community is great, who make new maps, scenarios, vehicles, etc, etc. Definitely worth the buy, especially for car fans, IMO.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Quick Summary:  BeamNG.drive was a surprise find for me.  It's an ambitious game that replicates realism and simulation on levels that other well known sim racers can't currently compete with.  It isn't without faults, of course, and there are areas where the immersion is broken.  However, I think a lot of this will eventually be addressed before the game actually releases.  There's a lot of fun to be had here, driving/racing enthusiasts should definitely give it a try.In-Depth:  The game is best described, in my opinion, as a sandbox driving game.  I hesitate to directly compare this to sim racing titles as BeamNG.drive feels more ambitious than that--it has racing, sure, but its scope is much larger.  Before I start going into the game further, my experience is based on playing the game using the following set up:Thrustmaster TX Servo w/ 458 wheelThrustmaster T3PA Pro Pedals w/ conical brake modThrustmaster TH8A ShifterRSeat ChassisPredator X34 monitorThe game detected my equipment fine, but did not automatically set everything up correctly by default.  With that said, I absolutely love how you can assign absolutely everything in the game to any button on your wheel or if you have a button box.  It also allows multiple mappings, so you can have keyboard commands simultaneously.  The overall UI is clean and easy to understand--it has a couple quirks, but overall very nice for such an early game.I have a pretty strong PC, and the game runs relatively well.  I'd expect for it to be even better optimized as it moves closer to actual launch, but its current state runs quite well.  I did have to run it in fullscreen or the game would barely run.  So if you are used to setting yours up as bordless windowed or anything like that, you may have to fiddle with some things to get it working properly.The game looks incredible.  Most racing sims really focus on the cars visuals, which makes sense, but track side visuals usually pale in comparison.  BeamNG.drive is much more even--the cars, interiors, and environments are all equally beautiful, which I'm a big fan of.  There are plenty of graphical settings, however, I mostly had everything turned all the way up to max playing at 3440x1440 and it was great.  I'm kind of blown away with how nice and even the game looks for being still early in development.On to the actual gameplay.  The game here is a bit split for me--at times (most of them), it felt like the most realistic driving experience I've ever had, but there were some times where the feeling was a bit off.  The few off times did seem to occur on paved surfaces, but it could also be the fault of my forcefeedback not accurately relaying to me what was happening with the car.  This is an area I think could use some improvement, the forcefeedback is present, but feels underdeveloped compared to the rest of the experience. (Assetto Corsa is my benchmark for forcefeedback)Now a bit more on why I would not directly compare this to sim racing games.  This game is so much more ambitious than that.  I would call this a driving simulator, not a racing sim.  There's a lot of variety here, and while it does have some racing, I was more impressed with its environments off-road.  I hope this doesn't sound like a knock on the game--I think it could be a great sim racing game if they focused on that, but this game is so much more.To the above point, there is a scenario mode which highlights all of the variety.  These scenarios are incredibly different from one another and provide a taste of what sort of possibilities there are for this game.  I won't go into them all, as there are quite a lot, but here's a couple:Car Delivery - Here you are driving a flatbed and have a sports car on the back.  You're tasked with delivering the sports car to its new owner.  You are timed and are required to deliver it without damaging it too much.Police Chase - Someone has robbed a bank and is making a getaway, you're tasked with stopping them.Van Jumps - There are some crazy jumps in this game, but the set you'll need to tackle with a van are some of the most difficult.This game has plenty more to offer including rally style driving, offroading, etc. There is also a mode that just lets you load up in a map and create your own fun.  You can spawn in multiple cars and objects, which allows you to set up some incredibly fun stuff.Now onto the game's main feature, it's soft body physics/damage.  This is by far in a way the most impressive thing I've seen in a video game in the past few years.  It's without equal to my knowledge, and adds a layer of not only realism, but also fun to this game.  It seems everything can be damaged, starting with the obvious body panels, all the way to individual axles, driveshafts, and engine internals.In closing, this game is very ambitious, beautiful, realistic, and fun.  There's a large variety of environements and driving surfaces.  This is a sandbox driving game at the moment and is amazing at what it does.  If you enjoy the chaos, destruction, and stunts of something like Burnout, or the make your own fun of any sandbox titles, you should definitely give this game a try.

Early Access Review
								This game is absolutely fabulous. I've played it ever since it came out, about 2 years ago in August. The very first version was completely different to what it is now but it has evolved a heck of a lot since then and it's fantastic to see. The game works fantastically and provides us with a very accurate simulation of vehicular physics, as well as free objects too such as walls, tires, wheels etc.This game doesn't have an objective, yet. However, if you were to play it, you'd immediately find yourself crashing cars in numerous different ways. Into other cars, through other cars, using the AI, throwing them from a cliff... The list goes on. The actual game itself is fantastic. It looks good and it feels good. The UI is friendly, simple and professional. It looks great and it works great. It's not something which will leave you feeling confused.There are lots of levels, open world levels, testing arenas, blank spaces and hilltops plus there is an entire modding community dedicated to making new, exciting terrains for us to use. The terrains look great, they're very well detailed and are huge! You won't be cramped here.Vehicles are a complete masterpiece. The original vehicles have a ton of detail and look incredible. Every single individual component in every vehicle is distinguished. You can see every strut, spring and shock absorber. When you aim the camera at the bottom of the vehicle, you will see the suspension arms and axles moving accordingly. You can see the leaf springs compressing and bumping against the bump stops. You can see all of this happening, in a game. The vehicles themselves are charismatic and each have their own unique handling characteristics from a small hatchback to a full on, mid-engined supercar. Or, you can drive a dual axle tractor unit. The list honestly is endless, as well as mods too. You won't find yourself short of vehicles to try. Each vehicle is individually customisable down to every last part. Do you want your car to only have a right door and no glass? No problem. Do you want your box truck to have engine tuning and 4WD? No problem. Do you want your pickup truck lowered to the ground and drifting? No problem! You can do it all.Finally, the game LOOKS incredible. Apparently, emphasis hasn't been put on to the graphics however if this is Beamng not trying, then they must be able!Don't be put off by the game's early access title. You may run in to some small bugs however their constant updates will make sure your gaming experience is fine. The game can crash, it can give you some painful times but they're not something that happens that often. Not in my experience and not in many other's either.I highly recommend this game, it's worth every penny.

								God damn this game is awesome, although I hesitate to call it a game by any stretch of the imagination. BeamNG.drive feels like it belongs in the "Software" section compared to the "Games" section of my Steam Library. Not a traditional game by any means, BeamNG.drive does its best to be the most detailed "soft body" simulator on the market. I've had hours of fun already just repeatedly crashing cars into the wall and watching them disintegrate in beautiful slow motion, makes the car destruction aspect of ANY OTHER GAME look like crap in comparison. So beautiful to watch metal deform and bend realistically and the guts of the vehicle's engine get ripped out from brutal impacts. If you like watching super slow motion crash safety tests and cars you will love this game.It's a pure sandbox more than a game, if you want races/ objectives you won't find much of it here, but what you will find is an expansive modding community that's added tons of levels and vehicles to the game, increasing its value significantly. There are also scenarios that you can race or just have fun trying to ram vehicles off the road. As long as you pick this game up KNOWING that it's a simulation and NOT a traditional game, you will find yourself enjoying it quite a bit. It's so addicting to just smash cars together, and eventually with the implementation of a "campaign" plus more standard racing modes I can see this game being an amazing product down the line.

Early Access Review
								The review in pro/con form from somebody who has been here from the beginning.Pros and Cons in list form; narrative below list:Pros:+A driving sandbox.+Soft-body physics make for amazingly realisitc crashes and deformation.+Excellent official content+Very good simulator for any vehicle you can imagine+Frequent updates (1-2 per month), each with lots of additions (like new vehicles) and fixes+Vibrant community+Modding!. Mods like vehicles, aircraft, maps, props etc. created by the community at the game's forums.+Pretty good visuals (some cons though) Supports up to 4K resolution (to my knowledege)+Full controller support+Local multiplayer (like old school Gran Turismo same screen multiplayer)+In-Game terrain editor.Cons:-Sounds (the team is working on this as a current primary objective. I will change this when new sounds are in the game)-Gameplay aspects lacking. Scenarios are available but are quickly played.-The lighting visuals seem really weird to me. Headlights are useless at night. I recently saw a quote that said that "the headlights are as bright as the sun with a cutoff" proving that there is a lighting issue.-? The force feedback feels weird; it could be that I don't have it set right but bumps feel rather numb.+/-Requires a rather good computer to handle (unless you turn off collsion between vehicles)NarrativePros This is a very good simulator in it's current state. There are not many game aspects to it yet but you have some scenarios given to you such as races or delivery missions. Despite limited concrete gameplay, this is very attractive because, in freeplay, you have total freedom to explore any map you have (official or third-party) in any vehicle you want (official or third-party). As of this writing (12/30/15), updates are becoming quite rapid fire with loads of new content in each.  From the launch of the game in August, 2013 to just about a year ago, you could tell that the team was struggling; updates took, in the shortest times, 3 to 4 months with mainly "improvements to physics" and little to no content additions. However, for the past six months or so, as the team has expanded with several new, talented members, every update has included a new official vehicle, bugs that the community have reported have been hit head-on, and the team's blog and other official information from the team has been clearly given and is more interactive than ever before. I have a feeling that Beta stage is almost here (currently the game is in Alpha)Moving on, the game comes with a built-in terrain editor. I have experience modding the game via the built-in terrain editor, it is capable and very easy to learn even just by trial and error. The community is vibrant and boasts hundreds of mods, be them vehicles such as cars, trucks, aircraft, etc., maps, utilites, and other etc modifications. I highly recommend this game be used with a good steering wheel and pedal setup (my personal bias is towards the Logitech series of wheels).ConsPutting the fact that better sounds are being made for the game all around, in their current state, the sounds are mostly lacking excitement. I concede that they have gotten miles better in recent months to include recently new unique sounds for one of the vehicles and most recently suspension sounds. As I said above, "gameplay" aspects are lacking. There are scenarios but that is it. The team has goals of adding a career mode but it hasn't been said when yet. This is probably personal but I feel that the force feedback system could be better.That's all I got :)Personal notes:Keep your performance in mind. The game IS VERY CPU heavy, not so much GPU heavy. Keep that in mind. I may go so far as to say that anything older than 5 years old will not play over 30 FPS; anything under 3.0GHz will not play over 30FPS (with collisions on). My 6 year old 2.3GHz gets me 10-15 FPS with collisions on, ~25-35FPS with them off. Overall:9.5/10 from me; the updates are very intriguing these days! The game truly gets better with every update.

Early Access Review
								UPDATE: It's been quite a while since I made my original review, and while the vast majoriy of what I said then still applies, there are a few things that have changed, all for the better! The game still has wonderful softbody physics, scratches still do not appear on the pain and the game still eats up a lot of my time. However, I can gladly say that BeamNG.drive now provides a much better driving experience. All the cars handle very realistically (not necessarily nicely however) as a lot has been overhauled. You now have control over tire pressure, tires will heat up, the engine will heat up, suspension has been completely overhauled and generally, the game handles a lot better. On top of that, there are several new official maps and vehicles, and lots of quality mods available. BeamNG.driver still isn't the best looking game on the market, and still has places to grow, but it's still certainly worth picking up and it keeps getting better and better!ORIGINAL REVIEW: As someone who's been doing small track racing in beat-up 4-cylinders since I was 11, I know a few things about damage modeling. I'm very picky with car games, especially ones centered around carnage. Beam.NG, is in my opinion one of (if not the best) soft-body car physics sandbox games out there. The damage portrayed is pretty darn close to the real thing. While it's not perfect it's as close as 2014 technology can really let us experience. Since it's still in Alpha, scratches and rubs don't appear on the side of the cars, but I certainly hope they will when the game is finished. However, while the damage modeling is wonderful, as far as a driving experience, BeamNG.drive doesn't deliver. If you want tight, accurate and realistic car control, look elsewhere. As of (Aug. 14 '14) BeamNG.drive isn't great to drive. The controls are sort of laggy, rear-wheel drive vehicles are near impossible to drive and the standard transmision is rather awkward. That being said, this game is still in developement, and I certainly recomend picking it up. As is, demolition derbies are sort of possible, but just messing around is tons of fun. I certainly enjoy it, and I want this game to become fully polished, so buy it and help it become the perfect driving simulator sandbox thing.

Early Access Review
								This game is absolutely fantastic. I can't think of a single negative thing to say about it- apart from some minor bugs, which are to be expected from a game this early in development. I've watched BeamNG's development since when it was first announced in 2011, and I think it's safe to say that there aren't any games even remotely similar to it. It is truly one-of-a-kind. BeamNG has hyperrealistic physics, leading to an extremely lifelike driving experience- including crashes. The terrains made for the game are beautiful, scenic, and fun to drive through. The community has made hundreds of different cars and terrains for the game, each of which are unique in their own respect.One thing I will say: though most of the cars and terrains on the BeamNG Forums are high-quality, some cars (and occasionally terrains) can be found on external websites (known as "Russian" mod distributors) that do not utilize BeamNG to the best of its abilities. Often times they are car models ripped from other games and placed on the node/beam structure of an existing developer-made vehicle. As a result, the physics and handling are poor and they tend to look strange and unrealistic in crashes. Generally, use of such mods is frowned upon, as they require little effort to produce and they frequently fail to properly credit the original publisher of the mod they are based on. As a general precaution, only obtain mods for the game through the official mediums (e.g. the forums or the upcoming repository).BeamNG is a superb driving sim and I'd recommend it to anyone who likes sandboxes and/or cars in a heartbeat.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Perfect game for any car fan, regardless of age. There's not a whole lot of fancy graphics, no lens flares, relatively simple smoke/dust effects, most foliage (except trees) are made of flat textures (which are pretty well done, you can't really tell unless you stop and zoom right in on the grass, looks fine if you're driving even at low speeds), and the shaders aren't modified to give a 'cinematic look'. So this game isn't an astonishingly pretty game. But you know what, that's okay.Each vehicle is intricately modelled, down to the point where you can see each individual part of the engine. You can see the butterfly valves on your supercharged V8 muscle car, you can see the engine block move around in its mounts slightly as you rev the engine. The level of detail is insane. Hit a harsh bump that bottoms out your custom, lowered car? Be prepared to potentially have your entire exhaust system ripped out of your car. Hit a sharp kerb at high speed? Might wanna watch your tires, they can pop, giving your car an unnatural feel. The physical damage in this game is brutally realistic, as each car is not 'hard-coded' with performance stats, health points, etc. Each INDIVIDUAL PART of a car makes up it's whole performance, much like a real car. Pop your front-right tire, and your car will start veering slightly to the right. Fit sport tires, you might be able to handle a corner slightly faster. Lower your suspension, you'll reduce body rolls and keep all 4 tires on the road better, resulting in better grip.It goes on and on. The soft-body physics overall are brilliant, the cars crumple, wobble, and react exactly how you'd expect a car to react.Maps:The maps that come with the game are very nice, and quite varied.Gridmap: A testing map, with an assortment of jumps, surface types (from sand and dirt to mud and water), slalom cones, objects to crash into and a few high-speed race courses.Port: A small map set on a port, a perfect map for Gymkhana or drifting fans, with all kinds of shipping containers, warehouses, and a few ramps along with it. Industrial Site: A medium sized map set on a seaside industrial area, it features a RallyCross track with multiple configurations, an offroad racing track laced with thick mud that will bog down your average rally car, but take a big 4x4 and you'll plow straight on through, and a more traditional tarmac race course. The industrial area also features many warehouses like the Port map, and a nice little circuit that races around it, featuring a jump over a small inlet.East Coast USA: Set in the East Coast of the USA (As the nae suggests), it has a medium-sized town, along with fairly well maintained roads, that go from the coast to snaking through the forest. Lots of dirt trails through fields and woodlands for rallying around too.Jungle Rock Island: On a Tropical Island, this map has poorly-maintained roads that call for terrifying high-speed driving along the coastline of this island. It also has many offroad dirt trails that run through the forest, and can quite easily end up getting you lost! There's also a few little rally trails, and industrial areas, quarries, and a port. Probably my favourite map.Cliff: Spawns you in at the top of a cliff, the only way around is down the cliff. Fun little map for just throwing stuff of cliffs and watching it arrive at the bottom as a mangled mess. Not much to the map other than that, but still fun nonetheless.Hirochi Raceway: A race-focused map, this raceway is GP-styled, with very wide, smooth corners, along with fast straights and chicanes thrown in. This map also has a few forest routes, that can take you on a narrow road through some forests, so any mistakes can be fatal.So, quite a few maps, with lots of variety.ScenariosThe game has a wide variety of scenarios, too many to list here, that cover multiple fun aspects of the game.These can range from tutorials, to shakedowns of various cars, police chases, races, delivery challenges, even a 'hyper-miling' challenge where you have to cross Jungle Rock Island with very little gas left in your car. There's even a demolition derby scenario for people to 'party play'.Overall, I'd give this game a 8/10, I'd like to see networked multiplayer (something the BeamNG devs might implement if their engine can support it) and a campaign mode (which the devs have planned pretty much since day 1 of the project)Lots more potential, the modding community is great, who make new maps, scenarios, vehicles, etc, etc. Definitely worth the buy, especially for car fans, IMO.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
Early Access Review
BeamNG.Drive has the weirdest name I've ever heard for a videogame ever.I can explain part of it, except the NG. You got me there.For reference, this is a car physics simulation game with some of the most true-to-life physics you can get.Anyway, back to the name. "Beam" refers to how the physics are simulated. The physics part of your car is built out of "beam," these invisible lines that make the physical mesh of your vehicle. They can break, which is where the damage starts to occur. They don't show it in any videos above, but it's definitely a fresh take on physics.Like I said, "NG?""Drive," on the other hand, is self-explanatory.Give this game a try. I'll be honest, the sound effects are basically worse than gargling broken glass (idk), and the visual look of many of the cars can make you gag (i.e the in-game Volkswagen Golf). If you're like me, you overlook those facts and say "OMG THE PHYSICS," unless you aren't a complete geek/nerd.Yes, buy this game. It's 25 bucks here, but look on their website! (HINT HINT, they have a humble store link right there that'll save you five bucks and still give you a steam key!)

Early Access Review
								Still Early Access, but this game shows potential!Having read a bit about the game, and watched the standard YouTube videos about it, I decided to give it a try. Now admittedly I haven't put in a whole lot of hours, because there still are some things that needs to be polished, before a final release is due.That being said, the game as it is now, is a lot of fun. The physics are unlike any other car game, which really is what sets this game apart right now.The handling of the cars is very unique, and not two cars feel the same. Depending on the type of car you have chosen, a simple task like driving down the road can become a challenge. I'll bet ya', you'll be wrapping your car around a few trees before you get the hang of the in-game handling.The game in its current state, already lets you do a bunch of different customization options, and I'm not talking about rims, speakers or the likes here, but stuff like removing parts of the body, removing a wheel, stripping the vehicle down to its core etc.All things that make the game kind of nerdy, but nerdy in a good way.The graphics are quite good too, and once you get the hang of controlling your car, you can start venturing into more advanced manuevers like handbrake turns, burnouts and whatever your heart desires.So for now, in Early Access, the game is for anyone looking to drive around some beautiful scenery, all while tinkering with different setups on your virtual vehicle, and just goofing around basically.

 My Beamng Drive Review First of all, Ive clocked well over 150 hours in this game :P it seems like a long time but when your playing beamng it simply flies by, it may not look like there is much to do but trust me, there is. Some nice things about Beamng Drive: The graphics are still really nice on lower settings.Alot of cars to play around with and create custom variations.A decent amount of dev made maps already in the game for you.Fun to just cruse around the maps and enjoy the sceneary! Some bad things about Beamng Drive:  The game is very resource intencive, but can still be played without recommended parts. Frequent crashes/Physics pauses due to some car bugs. Some (Almost all) mods are going to crash the game at some point. The Utah map is quite laggy due to size and amount of different hills.So, if you are thinking about getting Beamng Drive then you might as well, there is alot of fun to be had on this game and the amount of vehicles and variations is great, the cars are all very profesionally modeled and are unique to this game. Most of the vehicles are some sort of immitation of a real life vehicle. Mods There are an extreme amount of mods on the beamng drive forums and other websites hosting mods, there are alot of different mods including different engine mods, more vehicles, more vehicle variations and alot more!For me Beamng Drive is 100% 10/10, You have to expect bugs in physics games like these, they are made to simulate real life and usually dont have bugs at lower speeds... But high speed is still fun!

Early Access Review
								BeamNG.Drive is a physics-based driving simulator. It is not graphics intensive, but you need a lot of RAM to run it smoothly. Because it employs soft-body collision dynamics, it is capable of producing unimagineably realistic, *ahem* "accidents". driving faster than 70 mph puts you in a bit of a bind, as the slightest turn puts you at risk of a nasty crash. A little side-game can be derived from these low friction coefficients that are prevalent throughout the game, known simply as "The BeamNG Challenge". simply pick a map, pick a car, and try to stay above 75 mph. it's insanely fun and difficult, and a great way to challenge your friends that are a little bit too tired of playing Rocket League with you. This challenge is just one of so very many things you can do in this game.All in All, BeamNG is perfect for just farting around with physics and cars.

Early Access Review
								Click on the video below and watch some of my other videos to get an idea of what is all to do in BeamNG Drive. I have over 50 videos of BeamNG, from wheelie school buses to forward and reverse wheelie cars. There's exploding campers and instant destruction. Probably one of my favorite games/simulators. BeamNG isn't really a game, it' more so a simulator for crash physics. It's an open world based game, with hundreds of car variations. There's offroad, there's drag, there's drift, dirt, rally, you name it and someone has probably made it. The physics for the game are quite realistic as that is what they are going for. You can watch the suspension on your vehicle actually do what it's supposed to as you crawl over the mountains. There's ramps, there's objects to crash into, there's challenging maps that the wonderful BeamNG community have made, as well as the maps from BeamNG devs themselves. If you like to crash cars, and see the damage physics, and to play with the gearing and testiing what car can handle what, this is for you. I recommend this game many times over, even if you get it to let it sit in your library, to play once in a blue moon when you don't actually feel like doing anything. Sit back on the couch, hook up to your tv and just enjoy crashing.EDIT: I've played quite a bit since I first wrote this review and would like to add some things I've started to notice that really irk me. These won't change my recommendation at all, but it gives somewhat of an idea of what to expect, at least if you don't have a high end pc. My main issue I've come to just hate is how every map you download will have a different FPS rate. It doesn't matter if one map is huge and another is small. The differences are crazy. I'll even have huge maps that have wonderful FPS, while small maps are low almost unplayable. It makes no sense to me, but that's only because I don't understand how this stuff works. Trees. I'd rather not even have them in game. I use the no vegetation mod because they add unecessary lag. They rarely act as a tree would in a crash and it's annoying. I've hit a tree at 60mph and my car didn't slide through it and start grabbing in the middle of the car. With that, I'd just rather them gone altogether.I'd also like to add, that don't get offset by people's bad reviews, Most of them are not about the game itself, but because their PC can't run the game which I don't get how that's the games fault. I've seen reviews where people say there's not much to do. Well, there is. You can customize any map. Just be respectful and don't upload as yours and give credit if you make a video. I have customized almost every map I've downloaded. Just hit F11 by default and it'll load into the map editor. You can terraform, you can add roads, you can add water, you can change the terrain to beach sand which acts like sand and will flip your vehicle. Mud is available. Ice is available. Grass. The things to do are endless. The reviews seem to be based off their own ignorance rather than the game itself. "I can't drive without crashing", not the games fault, it's yours.  If you think there's not much to do in this game, then you should take another look at it because I highly disagree.UPDATE 0.8 REVIEW UPDATE: Graphics-I need to add in that the most recent update is amazing.  I believe For my PC, GTX 750ti. Intel i7 920@2.67Ghz. 8GB Memory DDR3. Windows 10 Pro I'm now able to turn off the 'no vegatation mod, (which obviously removes the vegatation from any and all maps, excluding some greenery that is placed in a different way) and have up to 4 cars with a good 30 to 40fps whereas before the recent Update I was getting 15 fps with 2 cars. I usually use cars from mods, not the direct BeamNG cars.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								So I'm going to cut right to the chase. The Good: An extremely accurate physics engine that does its best to simulate real life as closely as possible.  "Official" cars included with the game destroy and deform for the most part as you'd expect they would (you get minor bugs here and there but this doesn't often happen unless you completely mutilate a vehicle).  The official selection of cars is small, but steadily growing.  You get a selection of cars, trucks and SUVs with varying trim levels and options that you can customize. They're all very highly detailed and behave as you'd expect them to behave.  In addition to vehicles, there is a wide variety of other machines and devices you can use to destroy vehicles (including a roller crusher, a rollover sled, a giant hamster wheel and a car cannon).  The environments provided are again few, but nicely varied and include sections of countryside, small towns, racetracks, industrial areas and more.  The really big pro here?  The game is totally open to the modding community.  There are lots of cars, props and maps available to drive, and they run the gamut from plain family cars to rally specials and science-fiction wonders. The modded terrains range from rally stages to highways to elaborate obstacle courses to who knows what else.  The official terrains are very well designed and pretty, if a bit lifeless.  They're also quite large and have a lot of little secrets hidden all throughout them--secrets that can often only be accessed by a particular type of vehicle.The Bad: Despite being in production for well over a year, the game is still in a very early state.  There are lots of features still missing (there is no multiplayer, AI is primitive at best).  And then there's the other problem--this game is a MASSIVE resource hog.  All the physics calculations are done in real time.  There are ZERO canned crash animations, unlike a game like GTAV.  GTA uses canned animations to save on CPU overhead and preserve framerate.  Beamng.drive does not.  Because of that you are going to need a very good PC to run this game on high graphics settings and keep a reasonable framerate.  Also, because of the early state of this game there...really isn't all that much to DO.  There are a few "scenarios", basically all time-trial races, but other than these there's no real point besides driving around and figuring out new and inventive ways to destroy a late 90s pedo-van.  Also, this is a car-based driving game with car-based controls.  There are working boats and aircraft in the modding community but the control scheme is not designed to accomodate them.  Because of that they can be very hard to handle.  Another point against--the game works decently well with a gamepad (The X360 controller is supported natively), but to take full advantage of it you are going to need a decent steering wheel and pedal setup.  DO NOT attempt to play this game with just a keyboard and mouse. So should you buy this game now?  Well that depends.  Are you the kind of gamer that enjoys driving games?  Can you make your own fun?  Do you like to break stuff?  I'd say if you answered yes to at least two of those three questions, you should give this game a good hard look.  If however you're the kind of gamer that needs direction, needs to be given something to do, this game probably isn't for you.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								First off, I absolutely love this game. It's amazingly fun to just mess around with, and try to make really interesting crashes happen. This is definitely the most realistic car physics simulator out there, but keep in mind, that's about all it is. The developers have added some fun little missions to do, but they aren't really that good and you don't get any reward or even acknowledgement for beating them, they're sort of just there so the game isn't a complete sandbox. That being said, there is much more in the works, such as multiplayer, racing, and many other fun things that I cannot wait for. This also is a pretty big game, I'd recommend having a good computer to get the game's full effect. (My $200 Toshiba isn't exactly doing it for me) There are truly some amazing mods, including actual makes and models (ex. Ford Crown Vic, Ferrari F50, etc.) and even rocket cars and planes. They are up there with the stock cars the developers put out, work just as fine, and in my experience, have no extra bugs or glitches. (Though I do have to point out, you would do completely fine without mods because the developers did an truly amazing job putting out a variety of different vehicles, including semis, trucks, drift cars, your everyday sedans, police cars, hyper cars, vans, off-road variants of trucks, and sports cars. Keep in mind though that all of these cars are by fake car companies, so if you are looking for realism, download mods.)The other cool thing about BeamNG is that it is super-customizable. You can change the cars, (ex. remove/change parts or switch engines) change the time of day, mess around with the gravity, use slow motion, (Highly recommened, crashes look awesome in slow motion with the amount of detail in this game) and even add in AIs to chase you around or crash into. This is another fun aspect of this game that I love, and I use the features mentioned above a lot.Minor problems I have with the game:-Engine sounds. Most of the engine sounds that are in the stock cars the game comes with are the same, which can be sort of disappointing to a car guy. You do get some different sounds with modded cars, but you still get mainly one droning engine sound, which doesn't really sound good either. (UPDATE: This has been addressed and there is now a great variety of engine and crash sounds)-Water. In most cars, even the modded ones, going into water that is a little bit bigger than a big puddle on a real road kills the engine. This is really getting nit-picky, but when I try off-roading in a car that wasn't specifically built for it, even on just a bit of water, the engine dies. (UPDATE: This has also been addressed, and when your engine is getting flooded, the game shows what percentage of the engine is flooded, so you can try and get out of the water before your engine dies.)-Crash sounds. Almost every single sound of vehicles impacting something is met with the same exact sound. It is a realistic sound, but it gets annoying after a while hearing the same sound over and over when you crash it. (UPDATE: As I said before, this has been fixed and there is a great variety of sounds now)-Lack of actual gameplay. I did already address this, but once again, if you are looking for something other than a sandbox, wait for the game to finish Early Access or go somewhere else, because as of now, this is almost 100% a sandbox. Although there are a few things missing right now, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone with even a slightly better computer than mine and who just wants to mess around with cars and physics for a while. I have so far played this game for 80+ hours (Keep in mind I usually get around 15fps with my computer having -15 gb of ram) and I still have fun every time I open BeamNG. Updates are frequent and usually big, with either bugs fixed or new cars being added just about every time. Definitely buy this game if you want a sandbox, but you should wait a while if looking for real gameplay. Rating: 9/10

It actually saved my friend's car, because after playing a lot of BeamNG he had learned some subconscious reactions and instead of falling in to deep ditch at high speed we just scratched pile of snow, he admitted immediately that playing saved us, as he just got his driving licence and didn't had any experience, and his beginning with BeamNG was well... difficult but after a time he learned a lot of PROPER reactions. Anyway it's going to have more features like realistic transmission system, brake's thermals, tire's thermals, new sounds for every vehicle, more parts, maps, cars, real campaign with Street Legal Racing Redline themed garage and tuning, possible even online multiplayer improved existing content and features way more optimization, better crash physics and lots more. It's still like 2 years to full release, but it's worth the money right now. But you have to own not bad PC (look at required specs) and you have to know that there's no goal right now, no multiplayer you choose what to do, and if you're not creative you might get bored after 5 hours of smashing cars in different way. TBH I just race on Hirochi Raceway and I try to master every vehicle, driving here is very satisfying, especially when you have wheel like G25 or better and you are doing good ;) My biggest goal is to not crash, this isn't crashing simulator it's very good racing sim, but when you actually crash you have to look at this beautiful soft-body physics result.TL;DR-It's very good racing simulator-Can make you better driver IRL if you use good steering wheel-Requires something better than potato to play it-Will became better and better with every update, but to final release I estimate there are bout 2 years left-Worth the money if you can set goals to yourself -If you look for proper campaign or multiplayer, you'll probably get bored after 5 hours of crashing and you have to wait a little to not get disappointed, it's not for everybody. Requires some common sense thinking and knowledge how cars perform in real life instead of NFS series to not scream "cars feel to light", "cars feels like driving on ice", "cars are too weak" etc. (IMO they are a bit too strong, when you compare it to IIHS or Euro NCAP BeamNG's cars deform less, seems to hold a bit better but it's a game, most peoples can't imagine that after crashing at 30km/h they can damage car to the point it will not move)

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
Early Access Review
TL;DR summary:Overall BeamNG.drive is one of the best soft body car shenanigans simulator out there, and it's completely worth its price. I bought the alpha early on, about a year ago, and I'm still having fun with it now. If you like the physicsy simulationy type of sandbox game you'll definitely be impressed with BeamNG.drive and end up messing around with it for a long time (and that's not including the wide variety of mods available)!There's a racing mode and other new features coming out soon, and I hope they turn out as well as everything else.Regarding Next Car Game, NCG is more of a desruction derby focusing on wide areas and chunks of destruction with a ton of broken pieces flying around; it's more of an action-orientated game. BeamNG.drive is a realistic physics simulator sandbox. NCG and BeamNG.drive are both good at doing what they are designed to do, but in my view they're pretty different. TL;DR reviewy thing:Crash Physics: The physics are extremely realistic and efficient with minimal glitching; every crash inflicts different and varying amounts of damage upon each vehicle.Car Detail: The cars are detailed in terms of aesthetics (the detail of the exterior and interior of the vehicles) and mechanics (wheel torque, suspension, chassis integrity) with results extremely similar to their real-world counterparts.Graphics and Sound: The graphics are decent with no visual effect bugging as of now. The sound works for what it is but isn't made all that well; a sound overhaul is planned.Mods: The mods are plenty and great, very high quality. You can pilot airplanes and do the coolest trix.Controls: There are many controls and it is sometimes hard to press all the buttons needed to control vehicles. Vehicles can sometimes feel sticky or slippery.For those who are willing to take upon themselves the challenge of reading a huge block of text:Summary:BeamNG.drive is one of the most realistic car physics/damage simulators up to date. Utilizing a real-time soft-body physics engine powered by Torque3D, it successfully emulates breakable and malleable surfaces applied to cars. The physics demonstration that BeamNG.drive is capable of is nearly identical to real-world movement; footage of in-game crashes have been compared to real-world test crashes with minimal differences.Reviewy thing:Crash Physics: It's amazing how the physics are simulated, with every surface on every car bending and breaking differently in every situation (surfaces are warped in accordance to the surfaces they come in contact with resulting in unique damage, rather than calling up a stored "damage model" when a car hits something a la GTA car physics or the such). This is where the "Beam" of BeamNG.drive comes in. I'm not that knowledgeable about the details of the physics simulating but it can be thought of like a detailed, intricate grid on a surface with each point moving when it hits something. I have not encountered many bugs in the physics so far, but if pushed far beyond real-world limits the physics do cause model glitches. Sometimes meshes and textures will crumple and stretch weirdly after paricularly intensive crashes. For what it is, however, it works wonderfully and efficiently, even able to be run on a medium-powered laptop with some lag spikes only during intensive car mangling.Car Detail: Each car is crafted with a keen eye to their details; the mechanics of a vehicle and the aesthetics are both represented. Each car has its unique statistics, with varying engine types, suspension, handling, and et cetera. The handling can even be changed, with options for a sportscar-like experience, offroad handling, and other presets. (The actual in-game control handling can be changed as well, ranging from an arcade control scheme seen in most car games to a full, realistic "driver's seat" experience. However, as of now the control is sort of lackluster with a keyboard since the left and right keys make the steering wheel turn all the way to either side; the cars sometimes feel sticky or slippery.) The detailed aesthetics can also be changed, as the cars are modular and can have parts added and removed. This also ties in with the modding capabilities of the game, which I will get into in a bit. Because of all of the attention paid to making everything as realistic as possible, the seven vanilla cars each have their own unique feel and excel at different tasks (again much like their real-world counterparts).Graphics and Sound: In my opinion, there's not much to say about this aspect currently since the focus of BeamNG.drive is realistic physics simulation. The graphics are decent and look great when maxed out, but they're nothing special currently (as you can probably see in the trailer and screenshots). There are some post effects which help to smooth everything out a bit, and there are a spattering of particles here and there. The particles do add a lot of effect when used correctly in screenshots and cinematics. The camera following sometimes goes through the ground if a car is tumbling or spinning but overall works as it should, providing smooth views of third-person and first-person views (although there's no model actually driving the cars). That covers the basic graphics system, I think. The sound isn't as good as everything else, but it is clear and works its part. The engine sounds, tire screeches, and et cetera are the same in every situation on every car but the actual sound clips are clear and concise. In slow motion the sounds run in realtime and are very loud, but other than that I can't think of anything too jarring. There is some ambience as well, and it is decent. The developers are planning a sound overhaul, however, so I am looking forwards to that.Mods: The modding capabilities really expand the possibilities of BeamNG.drive, with more detailed vehicles, intricate maps, other fun and interesting mods. There are many high quality mods that have qualities comparable to the actual game. One of the most well-known modders on the BeamNG forums, DrowsySam, has even helped the devs with some things. Of course, as mods, they aren't completely perfect but as I said, most of them are top notch. There are even mods for planes, and althought the physics for those aren't as realistic and smooth as the car physics, they're still pretty awesome (the devs haven't had air travel possibilities in their mids yet so hopefully you can see how cool that is), I'm also not going to say too much about this, since you really just have to install some mods to get a sense of what they can do.Controls: The controls are a bit weird, with the arrow keys controlling vehicles, the numpad and a right-click-and-hold controlling the camera, and various other key combinations for respawning, changing gears (in manual control mode), switching vehicles, and activating slow motion to list a few of the commonly used commands. It works, but sometimes it is hard to access multiple commands, for example, when trying to record something (movement, camera angle, and slow motion for example).EDIT: Formatting and added something about Next Car Game.

The physics demonstration that BeamNG.drive is capable of is nearly identical to real-world movement; footage of in-game crashes have been compared to real-world test crashes with minimal differences.Reviewy thing:Crash Physics: It's amazing how the physics are simulated, with every surface on every car bending and breaking differently in every situation (surfaces are warped in accordance to the surfaces they come in contact with resulting in unique damage, rather than calling up a stored "damage model" when a car hits something a la GTA car physics or the such). This is where the "Beam" of BeamNG.drive comes in. I'm not that knowledgeable about the details of the physics simulating but it can be thought of like a detailed, intricate grid on a surface with each point moving when it hits something. I have not encountered many bugs in the physics so far, but if pushed far beyond real-world limits the physics do cause model glitches. Sometimes meshes and textures will crumple and stretch weirdly after paricularly intensive crashes. For what it is, however, it works wonderfully and efficiently, even able to be run on a medium-powered laptop with some lag spikes only during intensive car mangling.Car Detail: Each car is crafted with a keen eye to their details; the mechanics of a vehicle and the aesthetics are both represented. Each car has its unique statistics, with varying engine types, suspension, handling, and et cetera. The handling can even be changed, with options for a sportscar-like experience, offroad handling, and other presets. (The actual in-game control handling can be changed as well, ranging from an arcade control scheme seen in most car games to a full, realistic "driver's seat" experience. However, as of now the control is sort of lackluster with a keyboard since the left and right keys make the steering wheel turn all the way to either side; the cars sometimes feel sticky or slippery.) The detailed aesthetics can also be changed, as the cars are modular and can have parts added and removed. This also ties in with the modding capabilities of the game, which I will get into in a bit. Because of all of the attention paid to making everything as realistic as possible, the seven vanilla cars each have their own unique feel and excel at different tasks (again much like their real-world counterparts).Graphics and Sound: In my opinion, there's not much to say about this aspect currently since the focus of BeamNG.drive is realistic physics simulation. The graphics are decent and look great when maxed out, but they're nothing special currently (as you can probably see in the trailer and screenshots). There are some post effects which help to smooth everything out a bit, and there are a spattering of particles here and there. The particles do add a lot of effect when used correctly in screenshots and cinematics. The camera following sometimes goes through the ground if a car is tumbling or spinning but overall works as it should, providing smooth views of third-person and first-person views (although there's no model actually driving the cars). That covers the basic graphics system, I think. The sound isn't as good as everything else, but it is clear and works its part. The engine sounds, tire screeches, and et cetera are the same in every situation on every car but the actual sound clips are clear and concise. In slow motion the sounds run in realtime and are very loud, but other than that I can't think of anything too jarring. There is some ambience as well, and it is decent. The developers are planning a sound overhaul, however, so I am looking forwards to that.Mods: The modding capabilities really expand the possibilities of BeamNG.drive, with more detailed vehicles, intricate maps, other fun and interesting mods. There are many high quality mods that have qualities comparable to the actual game. One of the most well-known modders on the BeamNG forums, DrowsySam, has even helped the devs with some things. Of course, as mods, they aren't completely perfect but as I said, most of them are top notch. There are even mods for planes, and althought the physics for those aren't as realistic and smooth as the car physics, they're still pretty awesome (the devs haven't had air travel possibilities in their mids yet so hopefully you can see how cool that is), I'm also not going to say too much about this, since you really just have to install some mods to get a sense of what they can do.Controls: The controls are a bit weird, with the arrow keys controlling vehicles, the numpad and a right-click-and-hold controlling the camera, and various other key combinations for respawning, changing gears (in manual control mode), switching vehicles, and activating slow motion to list a few of the commonly used commands. It works, but sometimes it is hard to access multiple commands, for example, when trying to record something (movement, camera angle, and slow motion for example).EDIT: Formatting and added something about Next Car Game.

								I would like to pipe in and say that I absolutely love BeamNG Drive. There's nothing quite like it. It has its quirks, but as the game continues to mature, I find myself with less and less to complain about.Before you read further, let me advise you that you will need a beefy GPU for this game. I find it playable enough on my Nvidia GTX 960, and it's well optimised for what you're getting, but YMMV.Here's how I break the game down:+Unparalleled soft body vehicle physics model+Lots of beautiful, fully customizable stock cars that honestly just 'feel good' to drive+Awesome environments to drive around in+TONS of community content, most of which works and feels great. Posted: June 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Good stuff about the game below. Will update this as more updates come. Right now I'm guessing it's maybe 1% finished. The only content in the game are maps and cars (of which 99% is made by community). But the core is there. Also there are a couple of missions and races to try after the last big update.There are some amazing vehicle mods out there. And there are a lot of fun maps, too. Most people MIGHT get bored from the current state of the game though because there is almost nothing to do: You just load a map, choose a car, and crash it as you please. Or don't. You can drive around if you want. That's it. Oh you can add a stupid AI to follow you or run from you but that's about it. You can also add multiple AIs. They are also working on AI improvements as well.Now on to the good stuff: + I cannot emphasize enough how good the crashing mechanic is (flagship feature). It's ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. The game's name derives from the fact that they are using the Beam technology on car design (I think it's their own engine). The cars are created out of beams. That's why crashes are so realistic and fun. Every beam gets deformed on its own, according to the applied force, the angle of the force, the momentum and♥♥♥♥♥♥+ Beautiful graphics. To my taste, this is cutting edge+ You can even mod your own engine sound+ Mod maps and cars, or download the ready ones+ Day/night concept is there (editable)+ Destruct your car in a variety of ways+ Multiple cameras (duh)+ Slow motion at your disposal+ You're in for a lot of laughs+ Or join the modding forums on the website and be surprised to find out that someone designed your dream car into the game. Now download and crush it.+ Career is coming at full release+ ♥♥♥♥in' A**The only con I can think of is the required system to play the game at it's full capacity. I'm sure they will optimize it further but right now as it is, the game needs a powerful computer to run. Especially when you spawn multiple cars to crash or enter a foresty area. When crashing multiple cars together, it might lag a lot on average computers.**It has a vast potential, and the devs are aiming for a free-roam, career thingy, in which you will be able to buy junk cars and reform them into racing machines or pretty eye candies, you will be able to complete jobs, missions, races, deliveries, derbies, free-roam, all of that.But that would be a long way off from now. They say the game will be in this phase for about a year from now. So buy at your own risk (not that it's a risk actually, there is just not any content right now).When this game gets finished, it might be the very first 'driving' game that I have given 10/10 my whole life. Because currently there isn't any open world 'driving' game with realistic driving concept which also includes careers and mods. There just isn't any. Any potential rival games that come close to this, either ruin it by sucking at graphics or by making it online, or by making it a linear racing game (don't even get me started on NFS series).So I recommend it for people who like to smash cars with the best possible physics available, and who like community made cars and maps, and a realistic driving.There is also wheel support with manual gears.
