content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't usually write reviews... ever actually. But I feel this game can't go without one. I've been playing this game since September of 2013 and it simply never gets old. There is a lot of talk about there not being much gameplay yet, which is partially true. It doesn't have a story mode or a campaign, (Not yet at least) but to be honest it doesn't need to. The normal sandbox mode is endless entertainment, and with the new addition of 'Scenarios', (Time trials and timed challenges) there is more playable content than ever. The scenarios are actually quite difficult and it will surely take many hours to complete them all. And on top of that, you can share your times with members on the forum to be put on a leaderboard. Aside from the scenarios though, it's really a game meant for imagination and experimentation. Just thinking of every way possible to wreck any car I want leaves endless possibilities. As a kid who grew up on racing games, I've always dreamed of a game where every action you have has an equal reaction. One where you actually have to drive carefully in order to succeed. And that's exactly what BeamNG is. You can spend endless hours on this game whether you're crashing cars, flying planes, (And even sailing ships, soon) offroading, stunting, and even content creating with the excellent mod support this game has. It may get boring after an hour or two of just driving around and exploring, but for some reason I always keep coming back to it. I'll admit, it's not for everyone. It requires patience, imagination, and a curious mind. But honestly, if you've ever been interested in doing outrageous things with vehicles that you could never do in real life, than this is the game you need to get. It offers a ridiculous number of possibilities with real-life outcomes. It's truly the most realistic driving game I've ever played.Pros:Insanely beautiful graphics.Lifelike soft-body physics.Enough maps, cars, and objects to keep you entertained for days.Multiple 'Scenarios' where you can test your time and driving skill.Very advanced settings so you can set EVERYTHING perfectly.Customizable UI with multiple interesting apps.Camera mode for easy, beautiful screenshots.Extremely realistic vehicles. The models/textures are nearly exact in every aspect.Working dashboards, gas tanks, lights, and trailers.Real-life aerodynamics, time, gravity, and physics.Crazy props to destroy your cars with.Realistic maps that can take hours to explore.Time trials on supported mapsAmazing forum community.Easy mod support from the talented modders on the forum.*Mods such as planes, boats, offroaders, machines, maps, skins, apps, and more.Relatively easy to mod yourself, if you have the time to learn.TRULY regular updates. It's a small team but they really stepped up.Cons:Takes a decent computer to run well.Probably boring if you aren't a little creative.Crashes often (But what can you expect when you slam a car into a wall at 300mph in a virtual physics engine that's early access?)I don't personally use a racing wheel, but I hear the game has little support for them. I'd look into that more if this applies to you.TL;DRIf you've ever wanted to see or do anything crazy with a vehicle that you can't do in real life, buy this game. It's one of the most good-looking games I've ever seen, and it's the most realistic physics simulator I've ever seen. If you are at all interested in it, just get it.*I'd like to make this very clear that I said "on the forum". Never download a mod that wasn't originally posted to the official BeamNG forum. Around the BeamNG community, a few Russian websites have become very well known for publishing false mods. They are simple vehicle models ripped off from somewhere on the internet and then slapped onto the jbeam (The code and skeleton that makes vehicles in this game crash and function) of an existing default vehicle. This results in, for example, a car that looks like a Lamborghini but handles and crashes like a Crown Vic. These mods could have viruses in them, and without a doubt will not function well. If you do insist to download these however, I believe I speak for the community when I say to not publish videos or pictures of them. Like I said, they don't function the way they're meant to and in short, just make the game look bad. I just thought I'd give a fair warning.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								As of 6/17/2015: EARLY ACCESS.In it's current state, it's more of a car accident simulator than an actual game, though there are a few pre-cursors to a career mode - a few challenges and such.   This aside, let's get on to the real deal here.     An absolutely hands-down realistic soft-body driving simulator, most likely more realistic than what you see in drivers training computer systems.  Not only can you shift gears (multiple transmission modes, arcade automatic, real auto, manual, manual with clutch), you can use signals, hazard lights, headlights/highbeams, and the signal stalks and shifter moves as you shift it - gauges work too and if you clobber the car so badly the check-engine light comes on!.  It's extremely well thought-out, and if you ever have played Rig-of-Rods, it's all the fun that was, and way way more fun.      Welcome to the "Garry's Mod" of CARS.  I can't really explain it better than that.  When you fly too fast through a corner, and understeer, and nail a tree, your car becomes a crumpled undriveable mess of mangled steel.  This isn't GTA, this is a real simulation @ 2000hz (hz=times per second), with thousands of bits for each car.  Due to this, you need a beefy CPU to run this game well and a decent video card to go with it.  Anything i5/i7 or Phenom II quad core or better should run this, and it should be playable on an APU setup or i3 setup without too much fuss, though you might slow it down if you use the commercial truck as it has considerably more points to process.    MODS:  Loads of user-generated content for both vehicles and terrains (maps, levels etc), are available on the games website once you purchase the game.  You won't be let down by this as myself I am a big fan of game modding.  This program also INCLUDES ITS OWN LEVEL EDITOR INSIDE!  Woohoo!  More fun, and it's pretty intuitive to use, your mileage may vary.      For it's asking price, it's well worth it.  While it's not yet complete, this is more an adults game or a mechanics toy.  If you love cars, and realism, do give this a go!  You can even get computer controlled AI opponents to use if you dig around through the menus and figure it out - though in it's current state, it's either basic pursuit or to FLEE.  Can be quite fun near a steep cliff!     You can even change things like GRAVITY (or reverse gravity!) or make it the gravity of the SUN *CRUNCH*.  Wind direction/speed and cloud cover/fog can all be changed - though I am not sure if you can make it rain (yet) or not.   There's no music yet, and the sounds are quite basic at this point, but there is enough audio feedback to know what's going on, and it will be worked on more.  The graphics are beautiful (I think it's the crytek crysis 3 engine - don't quote me on it though) - and entirely up to par with today's game environments - but still scalable to your PC.  I have a recent model i7 and a radeon 7850 2gb and it runs this quite well with next to no lag.  SSD recommended but by no means required.  Some user levels can be 2gb so if you don't like to wait, put this on your SSD.   Keep in mind, when the game updates, you will have to re-install your mods (this won't usually be the case post-release but in pre-release early access it is, so just be warned!).  Keep your favorite mods backed up.    All in all, it's a good program for adults, and something to show your kid WHY NOT TO DRIVE TOO FAST!    A great program for the soon-to-be-driving teen-age member of your family!  Best used with a steering wheel or analog gamepad, as it may take quite a bit of time to get used to driving with a keyboard - it's that realistic.AGAIN:  HAVE AN ANALOG GAMEPAD OR STEERING WHEEL FOR THIS GAME, it's an absolute @$^# to drive with a keyboard (but it can be done, but you will crash A LOT).  Use the 'Covet' if you have only a keyboard and GO SLOW.Fun times - whole-heartedly recommended - a well made program!  I seriously have nothing bad to say on this one other than the fact that it's NOT done yet (but it will be!).Update 11/9/2015:  Played a demo-derby scenario - most awesome demo derby ever since Destruction Derby for dos in the mid-to-late 90's.  This is available on the beamng website under mods - you must try it!  Also, races with jumps and Honda spoon Civics ("Covet") and that's fun as can be.  You must give this game a shot, for 25 USD you can't go wrong!Update 12/2015:  Got a SCHOOL BUS vehicle out of the mods section on the game's web site, and a map with a large CLIFF.  Much fun & hilarity ensued.  Many pixels were injured in the making of that one.  Would bust the bus again 10/10.Update 1/1/2016:  Two recent updates have brought game version to 0.5.1, Two new cars, turbo and tuning systems galore, being able to mod the vehicle like you could back in STREET LEGAL, it's really becoming an awesome game/simulator.  More options now, more sounds (yay!), cars can catch fire, and the two new cars mentioned above (a vintage old 1950s car, and a 1988 import sedan) are pretty rockin' awesome.  Back to more fun on the large-cliff-map!

Early Access Review
								BeamNG interview between me and myself.Me: So how do you like BeamNG?Myself: I love crashing cars!Me: There are many games where you can smash cars. What makes this game so great?Myself: Three words. Soft. Body. Physics.Me: Soft body physics? Can you elaborate?Myself: Realistic and unlimited vehicle body deformation. More than any game before it. Before BeamNG there was Rigs of Rods. Burnout 3: Takedown has the best vehicular damage in the Burnout series. But that game did not simulate every component of the vehicle. Carmagedon, Dirt, Grid, Flatout and Crashtime all have pretty amazing vehicle physics. BNG is just leaps and bounds ahead of everyone.Me: Would you recommend the game, even in the early access state?Myself: Absolutely yes! If your PC can handle it. This is probably the only thing holding the game back. The game is still a work in progress so at times the game runs great, other times not so much. There is a mod community already making vehicles for the game. These can be hit and miss as different versions of the game come out compatiblity changes. So if you find a car that just falls apart you might have to uninstall that mod. The developer content in the game is great so far. Constantly adding new vehicles, maps and scenarios to play. I just love to load up a map and play around with the many vehicle types. It's essentially a physics playground of vehiclular vehicle slaughter.Me: Wow! that is a lot to take in. Hopefully this answered some questions for the community looking to buy.Myself: Well if you want you can swing over to my profile page and check out some of the screenshots that I took in game.Me: Great. I will. Thank you for our time.

Early Access Review
								If the devs read this, please make the clutch necesary when in manual.After 70 or so hours I figure I should write a review on this game.First off I would like to correct the store page, when it says local co op it's a competitive demolition derby, it's is a very different style of gameplay to the regular driving, it's unique and very fun in it's own way, however it does require at least one other person to be there with you. Soooo I personally don't like reading the big long in depth reviews so I am just gonna put some pros and cons say a few final words and be done.Pros:-Good graphics-Pretty good sound fx-delicious phisics-Lots of fun scenarios (more added frequently and community made scenarios)-Lots of player made content-Level editor/creator (never used it myself but it's cool that it's there)Cons:-You dont need to use the clutch to shift even when in a "fully manual" driving mode.-Nearly unplayable on a keyboard (wheel is best, but I put a good 30 of my hours on a gamepad)-Not very well optimised (on a normal $450 computer on min graphics I got around 30-40 fps, now I have a great gaming rig and I get a solid 60 fps unless I turn on dynamic reflictions, then I get 40-55 fps)-Takes a little while to set up a wheel for it-When you get driving it steals hours (I once drove for 4-5 hours straight in the same car on the same map)Bottom line, get the game if you like deystroying things, driving or if you just like cars generally. It's frequntly updated and they are always improving it.Ps, I basically learned to drive manual in this game, even though you don't need the clutch I used it anyway and now I shift gears with clutch without thinking.10/10 would buy it again.

								This is a great game.  I've always loved driving games that simulated damage and whatnot.  Need for Speed once used to do this, and I loved it. content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
Some of the finest physics I've seen.BeamNG.drive is a driving game/tech demo hybrid with an impressive amount of detail and surprisingly addicting. Having started as a proof-of-concept in the CryEngine by the former developers of Rigs of Rods - another very similar, more rudimentary game focusing on trucks and heavy vehicles, it has since switched to the Torque3D engine to handle the physics.There's no storyline or career as of yet. Updates have added a selection of campaigns to complete, such as a driver's license test and wrecking stuff up.It's a pretty game, for sure, but don't go nuts with the dynamic car reflections if you treasure your framerate. Rather odd post-processing artifacts, or that might be me just not knowing how to work with them. Crashes look a little bland without particles or extra bits flying out.Sounds remain fairly basic, with the standard game offering a grand total of two distinct engine notes without mods: an Inline 4 and a V6/V8. No soundtrack, either. The variety of impact, crash and general effects is increasing, at least.The selling point lies in the revolutionary soft body physics. At the expense of requiring an ever more powerful CPU to simulate multiple cars interacting with each other, you get what is possibly the most accurate car deformation, period. While it remains prone to clipping, gripping and other odd issues, 99% of the time it is consistent and logical.An ever expanding list of official cars cover more or less any stereotype conceivable, and if you can think of more, there's mods to remedy that too. You can drive a 4-wheel steering sedan, a pickup truck for your hillbilly rock climbing purposes, a surprisingly fun and nimble hatchback, a dangerously difficult 70's supercar, and many, many more. All of them, of course, have varying tolerances to crashes from whichever direction, but also a healthy collection of parts to choose from. Slap a stage 4 supercharger kit on your muscle car and rocket to terrifying speeds - and send your engine temperature shooting, your wheels screeching due to no grip, and your hapless car careening into walls.It is such a robust and well built engine that it can simulate airplanes and helicopters, lift and drag, and all sorts of intricate stages of mechanical failures like blown engine gaskets, fried piston rings, bent connecting rods, broken driveshafts, snapped axles, faded-out brakes, so on and so forth. It has taken a few years to get to this point, but man: it is the most impressive evolution of a game I've ever seen, from release until now.Mods further increase the game's variety, with aforementioned planes, helicopters, and varying flavours of land vehicles and configurations. Simple to install and remove (usually).Updates are somewhat slow to deliver, but when they land, you should expect a couple more cars, a lot more car variation, and several new, possibly experimental systems to improve the simulation aspects of the game. I dare say the devs have picked up significant momentum as of late, and they're eeking ever closer to proper LAN, or even online multiplayer. Until then, we have replays and AI control to bring our destruction derby and "Slightly more sensible Crash Junction" dreams to life.It is totally worth the money if you're a car/physics nut. It surely is deep in its mechanics, but the current content is a bit too thinly spread to easily warrant a purchase for anyone else; patience is a more wise idea when tackling Early Access titles, even better developed ones such as this.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is definitely one of the best racing games I've ever played.  Its fun, realistic, and creative, thanks to the dedicated mod community and wonderful devs who keep us updated on their website beamng.com/blogs/ with a weekly summary of their work.  I've put at least 20 hours into the game before it came on Steam, and I have no intention of stopping.  This game already has no ceiling to how amazing it can be, and there isn't even any sort of structure to the gameplay.  Its a simple load map, load vehicle, drive to your heart's content affair that is both incredibly relaxing and engagig.  I love making rally courses to run through without wrecking and just running through them over and over.  There is no time limit, no opponents, and no objectives.  Only you, the car, and the road.  The great bit is that each game is a new adventure because there aren't any rules as to where you can and can't go, leaving it up to you to decide how to explore and play with the environment you're given.  And then there is the main selling point of this game: the crash physics.  How the devs did it, I have no idea.  Watching your car get bent in half around a tree after a botched high-speed turn is a sight like no other.  For those of us hell-bent on obliderating our cars, there is a map called "Insane Testing" by Insanegaz on the mod forums featuring spikes, loops, giant stairs, huge drops, high speed cliff races, and all kinds of terrains to smash your vehicle on.  As well as being a great game to play, it is also a great game to mod.  The world editor can be accessed by pressing F12 in game, and it uses a simple and intuitive UI that makes it easy to create your own content.  On the coding side, everything is done in LUA, which is incredibly simple to learn.  Installing mods is as easy as downloading one from the forums, unzipping the package and dropping the folder into the appopriate directory within the game file ("Levels" for new maps, "Vehicles" for new cars, etc.).Of course, there are a few problems with the game, but that is to be expected of a private Alpha build.  The engine sound is the same for all cars, and the tire screech is not pleasant either.  There is currently no multiplayer, although I expect that to come eventually.   At the time of writing, the dev team is in the process of crafting a massive update nicknamed the "Race Update" because it is to add a structured race system complete with laps, checkpoints, and working AI (non-player vehicles are currently a feature, and they do have AI, but only "Flee from player" and "Chase player", both of which are tons of fun already).  Some of the controls are a little obtuse (I'm sure they're just placeholders that will be changed by Beta), and there isn't any GUI for customizing your controls.  In fact, you have to find your inputmaps.dae file and manually edit things, which is a little annoying, but not a game-killer.  While the crash physics are amazing, the rest of the graphics fall a little short.  As a whole, the textures are somewhat lifeless and the lighting isn't advanced enough yet to add a solid tonal feel to the game.  BUT, the game isn't anywhere close to being done and I am quite impressed at the quality and sheer amount of fun present in this piece of software.

Early Access Review
								At first I saw this game as a fun crash simulator. As I played more, I became fascinated at how realistic the driving physics are, despite employing a completely different paradigm to anything else. In the past, i've found physics based titles (not just car games) to have a plethora of silly physics glitches, making them difficult to play or impossible to take seriously. I bought a Thrustmaster T300RS Racing wheel recently, and despite having a dozen other car games in my collection, I find myself coming back to this one. It really shines with a wheel, and you'll find that the force feedback is a unique experience compared to anything else. Oh and the crashes are spectacular of course.Recommended.PROS+ Surprisingly nice graphics, looks almost raytraced at times+ Novel approach to vehicle handling that that is fun but realistic+ Industry-leading softbody physics+ Good controller support, with support for shifters and clutch pedals. I'm even using an old joystick as a handbrake.+ Force feedback for wheels is great when tuned+ Mod support; more vehicles, more maps, more funCONS- Poor performance on a 980 Ti a good bit of the time. 45-50 FPS in a lot of maps.- Needs some tweaking to get ingame steering wheels to turn 1:1 with your wheel controller- No multiplayer... yetNEUTRAL- VR support better be on the roadmap- Steam Workshop would be better than the current mod install system

								BeamNG Drive Early Access. I bought this game a while back and I finally got a Steam key. So here is my review. BeamNG Drive is a driving simulator but not really. I think it is more of a vehicle crash simulator. The crash physics are great and the driving physics are getting there. I really like it. The biggest thing that bugs me is the computer performance. Now, I may not have a gaming PC but I can play other games on medium-high graphics and have no trouble. But on this game, it struggles. A little problem is clipping and fall-through. Clipping is when I crash into another vehicle and the textures clip into each other. Therefore wedging the cars together. Fall-through is my term when a car falls through another car. For example, loading the hatchback into the box truck (of course I remove the doors). I drive the car in and it falls out the bottom of the truck. The bad parts are little enough where the good parts stand out. Overall, a great game. I recommend it.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								There's a lot to BeamNG Drive. It's probably best known because of the amazing, unique, real-time physics make the cars deform very realistically. Most games that have a decent damage system only seem to deform very well somewhere past the more gentle bumps and bashes, but somewhere before the really extreme, high-speed crashes, that would turn a car into mangled pulp, which does take quite a lot of joy out of that insane crash-stunt-thing that you managed to pull off.BeamNG, though, as the damage is calculated while you are crashing, will have the cars deforming well no matter what end of the scale you push it to- you can watch the very slight deformation that comes from driving a car slightly too hard, and see the little dents and and bashes, all the way up to the car being crushed to such an extreme that the car is left only a couple of inches tall- a phenomenon that is usually caused by setting the gravity to a level that makes the cars float off the ground, before suddenly changing the gravity levels to that of the sun itself.But, although that is all amazing, and can bring a LOT of fun, and be interesting to observe, it is not the focus of the game, and it is, for me, not the best part of the game.At the time of this review, there are three environments that I consider particularly noteworthy, and a few smaller environments. All of the maps are extremely detailed, and contain a lot to explore. They don't even prevent you from leaving the roads! Sure, there isn't a huge amount to find away from the beaten path, but if you're like me, then you've probably had that moment in a racing game, when you've just stopped and looked at how beautiful the landscape is, and had a strong desire to go drive all over it. BeamNG won't surprise you with anything super-amazing if you try to do that, but it won't disappoint, either. That hill will be there, and you'll be able to actually drive all over it, and it will be almost exactly what it looked like it was- although, I will note that it will, in one or two maps, while still turning out to be what it looked like, Also reveal that at the bottom of the other side of the hill, the map suddenly ends in a void. It isn't a huge thing, but it would be a bit more immersive if they'd thrown a random ocean there, or something.Then, of course, most importantly, there is how the cars feel when you drive them. This is probably the main point of the game, and the most important aspect of any racing game.Now, they handle very realistically-there are a few issues to iron out still, but heck, it's an early alpha game and they've already got it THIS realistic? It's pretty insane. But, I'm going to focus on how it feels to drive them. This is the most important point for most gamers, if they are not hardcore simulator fans.A lot of people have been complaining that the cars are too hard to control, but I'm just using a Logitech F710 -that is, a gamepad with the layout of a PlayStation controller, that emulates a 360 controller, minus the deadzone- and it isn't TOO hard to control the cars. They’re a little hard to control if you’re trying to push them to their limits, but they’re not too hard, and you can always just drive them gently, which is plenty easy.In fact, I don't understand why this game is getting flack for how hard it is to control the cars, when games like Assetto Corsa seem to have few complaints, yet, when I'm playing Assetto I often find that one minute the car feels like it's very stable, and despite the fact that I'm starting to slide it, it feels like I have a LOT of control- then, suddenly, because I applied slightly too much throttle, I find myself backwards and in a cloud of tyre smoke, without any warning, wondering what just happened. BeamNG, though, feels so...Natural. Nothing feels forced. If I push too hard, I can see very clearly that the car is slipping out of my control, which sometimes gives me enough of a chance to catch it before it spins- or, at the very least, to put the game in slow motion so that I can watch as the dents form in the car.Y'know, I've always had a thing about watching cars leaning and/or bouncing on their suspension. I can’t really describe it.This game succeeds in giving me the same kind of feeling I get from watching a car's suspension smoothly dealing with a sudden change in elevation, or dealing with the weight shifting to the front of the car under heavy breaking, in real life; I don't remember ever getting that feeling from another game.And, of course, I could talk for days about how detailed, and beautifully designed the cars in this game are. They are very similar to cars that are in reality, yet they are not blatant ripoffs; they have their own look, and their own charm...Rather like real cars do. They are FAR more detailed than the models in most games, and if you pay attention, you'll notice that the interior of the car is actually part of the model, and you can see it in all it's glory from 3rd person view, if you manage to get the camera to be looking in the window....I'll stop here, before this gets any longer. Even as it is, it'll be a pain in the neck to proofread.I will note, though, that the game is very resource intensive. back when I got the game (the day after it was first released), I only had an old-ish laptop, and, as I expected, it got an average of about 20 FPS with the least CPU intensive cars, which was not very playable. But, I now have an AMD FX-8320, which is OC'd to 4.4 GHz, and a Sapphire 7870 HD, and it runs the game as smoothly as a Codemaster game's menu animation. You should make sure that your computer has enough power before you buy the game, or you may be somewhat disappointed. And, don't expect to be able to run a tonload of cars, either. If you have a good CPU, you'll be able to run about 6 cars at once.Also, don't expect a complete, polished game, because it isn't. It's an early alpha release, being worked on by a VERY small team, and this game is more advanced than any driving game before. EVER. So don't expect it to be developed at lightning speed. The devs are releasing updates at a good pace, but the bigger changes and features can take a few months to implement, and there are a few [small issues] to deal with at the moment, such as slightly tacky engine sounds.TL;DR: Amazing physics, good graphics, good maps, good devs, good game. Shut up and take my money. And the money of whoever is reading this review, for that matter.I expect I'll come back in the future and update this review as the game progresses.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								First let's do the obious: Would I recommend this game? Yes, but with big disclaimer. At it's current state there is not much "game" in this game. It's just incredibly accurate physics simulator sandbox with cars in it. But as an engineer I've lost my heart to this thing. I've banked incredible hours into this game before steam release just crashing stuff and sometimes generally trying to stay on the roads. Let me open that "generally trying to stay on the roads" don't even think about that trying to do anything else than crash cars into various objects next to the object you aimed for with just keyboard controls. The cars are incredibly twichy to drive without precision control like in any driving game aiming for high- to ultra realism in their drivingmodel (and no driving aids). Xbox360-controller, yes good start, but I would recommend somekind of steering wheel for any tries to stay on roads. Altought at this moment you should be prepared to do some input mapping manually with notepad etc, if you have older or more exotic wheel and even then force feedback is no-go (Xbox360-controller works great straight out of the box).Then few words about cars and tracks included at this moment. They are good start, but one sportcar one 90's saloon, frontwheel driven hatchback, van, musclecar and pickup are quite limited choices (I won't mention the threewheeler as it is right now completely undriveable). Also out of the six maps there is just three actual ones to drive around and they have very little variance between them. The rest three are just empty map, big hill to make your car look like raisin and a crash testing field. But as with this game's spiritual predesessor ROR there are community made maps and cars, and oh boy there are those. Ranging from poor mods made by sticking something like Audi R8-model on the games sportscar Jbeam map without modifications to it (so that the car stars to crumble before it actually hits anything) to completely custom made models where you actually can nearly put your crash results next to euroncap footage and not see no big obious differences. Altought most of the older ones you can find most likely won't work correctly as they made some changes lately that can break models made before that update. From the map side I've not yet come accross a incredible map, but some ok-ones I've tested. This tought I'm sure will selfcorrect as this game comes available here in steam as this game includes as far as I can understand pretty comprehensive level designing and customising tools. NOT USERFRIENDLY, but comprehensive!As I wrote would I recommend this game at the start, let me end by writing what I've like to see in this game. Firstly ofcourse is to see some actual "game"-like systems implimented. Some of these like basic checkpoints for racing etc. I've understand are just few updates away, but that career mode promised in that trailer sounds like a dream come true if they manage to get it out sometime. Second thing I'd like to see is Steam workshop support for easier installation of the community made models and maps. Third I'd like to see more cars and maps in the vanilla version, mayby even if they would manage to get some real cars licenced for this game it would be great. But as car makers are what they are I understand that this might be just a pipedream and we'll have to settle just in the community made mods in that front...

								*Updated at Steam Release*This game is probably my favorite driving game of all time. Hands down. See how many hours I've played it? And that's just from Steam Experimental Release to now. I probably had 75-100 more hours before that.The game runs beautifully, and simulates perfectly. If you are deciding whether or not to buy this, let me give you the REAL pros and cons.PROS:- Large Community online, creating new vehicles, terrains, etc- Many vehicles already in-game that work flawlessly- Physics to the extreme, you feel every bump, and so does your car.- The map quality is phenomenal.- Customization is fun to mess with.- Built in terrain editor!- You won't get bored. Logitech G27 Master Race.- BEWARE RUSSIAN MODS FOR THIS GAME.I have an Intel i7-3770S with Intel HD 4000 Graphics, and I run the game with Mesh/Texture Quality on Normal and Lighting/Shadow Quality on Lowest and get good fps all around. This game takes a lot to run, which is understandable.OVERALL:Buy the game. It's worth whatever you pay for it. The game is only going to get better, so why not get it now? IT IS WORTH EVERY CENT YOU PAY. I SWEAR.If you are looking for the ultimate crash testing, car smashing, racing, drifting, customizing, community-involved car game out there, it's this.Note: This game is much more enjoyable with a racing/steering wheel or controller for turning movements. I personally use a Logitech G27, and it is so worth it.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								I played a lot of video games in my youth. But I put them away when I reached adulthood. But one day I saw the BeamNG Drive trailer and was impressed. And so for the first time in about 20 years, I bought a video game.  Yes, only a game this good could break my 20 year drought!This is seriously the best video game I have ever played! The game offers the rare combination of being simple yet profound. It's uncomplicated to play, but allows you to do so much. The producers continue to innovate with each new update, making the game better and better and more interesting. The graphics and maps are often visually stunning with incredible detail. Many of the maps are so interesting with so much to do, they could almost be separate video games themselves. Plus, I love how other people can create maps, vehicles and props for the game. I also love the flexibility the game provides. In free roam, you can make up your own missions and goals. As well, if you're short on time, you can teleport to any place on the map, rather than spend time driving there. One of the game's best features is the soft-body physics technology, which makes crashes exceedingly realistic. Plus, there are almost endless ways you can damage and crash your car. It never gets old! It's so powerful that rather than merely playing a game, you're having a new experience! Just be aware the game is demanding on your computer. A graphics card is recommended but not required, if you have a pretty good computer. However, a few minor  features in the game may not available without a graphics card.In sum, BeamNG Drive equals video games at their best. BeamNG Drive is the quintessential driving, crashing and racing video game and the gold standard. I believe this game will be the top video game of the 21st century. Don't miss out and give it a whirl!

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you love cars and all the physic's that go with them, then this game is for you. If' you're looking for the next racing game however, keep looking. BeamNG is the most realistic physic's simulatior I've ever played, is it perfect? Absolutly not. But it's very very good, among the best of the few games it compares to. It is so easy to turn on some music, or listen to book on tape and get lost for hours on end just driving around in your sandbox, racing, crashing, towing, testing or just exploring. Perhaps most importantly the dev's actually care about this game...One of the drawbacks to buying / playing early access game's is that it is often a gamble. A lot time's the devs become tired with their product and halt devolpment all together, leaving you with a hole in your wallet and a half finished product that'll never be more than that. That however, is not the case here. I owned this game for almost a year now, and throughout that year I have witnessed consistent improvements, patch's and added content. I cannot praise this game enough, I don't have the time to invest thousands of hours playing games like some people do. But I beleive this is my second most played game on steam...Only surpassed by Skyrim, and for the record BeamNG is closing fast on my Skyrim hours. The game has a decent arsenal of vehicles, ranging from your run of the mill work truck (which can modified to suit your taste) to Race cars, to Semi tractor trailers. And the fact, that this game is Steam Workshop compatible mean's that even more vehicle's and track's are just a click away!I'm trying to think of some potential ''con's'' to weigh in with all the ''pro's'' that go with this game. Personally I would like to see even more customization implimented into the game, such as the ability to tune gear ratio's in the transmission and fine tune things like aero dynamics. It would also be nice to be able to add specific upgrade's to your vehicle's engine. As it stand's right now, most vehicle's have Stage 1 Stage 2 and Stage 3 engine tune's and/or intake's that give you three stage's of horsepower/torque. But that's really just cherry picking on my behalf. Let's see what else, For those of you who enjoy playing with others...This is not your game. To my knowledge it currently does not have any form of multiplayer. No internet race's, I heard one time that it has split screen playability, but it's not something I've ever tried to use. I've heard some complaint's that this game only run's good on bad♥♥♥♥♥desktops, which is not completely true, however their's some truth in that statement. My current desktop was top the of line...Eight years ago, which my graphic's turned down a bit I can run most of BeamNG just fine. Howver, until I get a new computer I cannot play on certian level's...Like Moab, it's just to much for my old machine. On the side of sound, it's currently fairly weak. All vehicle's sound the same, a turbo I4 sounds excatly the same as a modified big block V8 in this game, so there isn't a huge veriety in that area, but hopefully that'll be improved upon in future patch's...Personally I just play with the sound off and listen to Reddit horror stories on Youtube while playing. With that said, It's time to tally up the Pro's and Con's.(Pros)AMAZING Physics.Reliable Devs who invest in their product to make consistent improvementsPotential to get lost for hours playing.Immense depth in level's, lot's of exploration to be done.Decent veriety of vehicle's ranging from Pickups to Race cars to Semi's.Supports Steam Workshop, meaning downloadedable vehicle's and tracks are just a click away.(Cons)Taxing to run at high resolution.Needs a little more depth in vehicle tuning.Lame sound effects.In it's current state I give this game a solid (9/10)It was worth every penny I spent on it. I hope you enjoyed this review!

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's actually pretty good. You do need to mind the system requirements though as the graphics look nice but hit your system hard especially on starting a session since the game loads the entire map and every little part on every car at once. As for the gameplay the collision effects are really well done and you can do whatever you want to. The sound effects really are poor and fake sounding though as most mobile games have better sound effects and the handling of the cars is unrealistically poor. But it does have pretty fun levels and challenges you can do to make you realize just how fragile cars are. Like oh you hit a rock at 5mph now your steering needs to be fixed. It's coming across like a vehicle based Gmod since you can also just mess around with physics. But like Gmod it does lack content at its base level and so mods and multiplayer are needed to really make the game great. Unfortunately the modding is not very streamlined and would be better through the steam workshop or a dedicated mod site like nexus. If you want to add real cars you need to search around for them on all sorts of sites and clearing the cache to fix texture bugs removes them you'll always need to keep backups. In the end it's just a fairly fun way to pass some time but the mechanics and sound aren't polished enough to get immersed into it. Because there is no real objective it's hard to call it a game. It's more like software with games in it and mostly challenges you make for yourself right now. Gotta use your imagination until it gets to the point where you don't have to.Overall it's pretty good for an alpha car/physics sim but nowhere near beta or release quality. I'd wait for proper mod support unless you are a car enthusiast in which case I'd suggest buying it whenever it is on sale.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								if you like games with realistic damage...if you like the idea of an 800+hp drag monster that can literaly twist itself appart...if you ever wanted to know what driving a car with a ruptured fuel tank that catches fire with the slightest spark...if you ever wanted to do the mythbusters car between 2 big rigs...if you ever wanted to try the mythbusters finally with the plow on a truck...(this list could go for days)...then this is the game for you.if you clip a wall and crack the radiator then you can overheat and blow the engine. if you jump a car and twist it then it will pull to a side, if you jump it too far it will snap the driveshaft, mangle the car and you can doo it all in slow motion (built into the game)the closest game i can compare this too is GTA4 for a damage model BUT the cars turn. if you rub a wall or other car wrong you can pop a tire or bend your steering. if you think adding a masive supercharger to a big bock muscle car and putting skinny tires on it sounds like a challenge then your right.as the game sits now (aug/4/16) there are a few small bugs here and there but nothing game killing.the main thing i recomend is that you check your computer for the minimum requirements and expect to need a little more than that. i can play this just fine on my old laptop (samsung rc512) and its like 4 years old.overall its a 10/10 for stupid fun (once you learn what your doing, treat it kinda like a racing sim where you need to practice a little to get good) its easy to learn what your doing and once you wrap your first car around a tree or throw it off a cliff then you'll fall in love

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								I played a lot of video games in my youth. But I put them away when I reached adulthood. But one day I saw the BeamNG Drive trailer and was impressed. And so for the first time in about 20 years, I bought a video game.  Yes, only a game this good could break my 20 year drought!This is seriously the best video game I have ever played! The game offers the rare combination of being simple yet profound. It's uncomplicated to play, but allows you to do so much. The producers continue to innovate with each new update, making the game better and better and more interesting. The graphics and maps are often visually stunning with incredible detail. Many of the maps are so interesting with so much to do, they could almost be separate video games themselves. Plus, I love how other people can create maps, vehicles and props for the game. I also love the flexibility the game provides. In free roam, you can make up your own missions and goals. As well, if you're short on time, you can teleport to any place on the map, rather than spend time driving there. One of the game's best features is the soft-body physics technology, which makes crashes exceedingly realistic. Plus, there are almost endless ways you can damage and crash your car. It never gets old! It's so powerful that rather than merely playing a game, you're having a new experience! Just be aware the game is demanding on your computer. A graphics card is recommended but not required, if you have a pretty good computer. However, a few minor  features in the game may not available without a graphics card.In sum, BeamNG Drive equals video games at their best. BeamNG Drive is the quintessential driving, crashing and racing video game and the gold standard. I believe this game will be the top video game of the 21st century. Don't miss out and give it a whirl!

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you love cars and all the physic's that go with them, then this game is for you. If' you're looking for the next racing game however, keep looking. BeamNG is the most realistic physic's simulatior I've ever played, is it perfect? Absolutly not. But it's very very good, among the best of the few games it compares to. It is so easy to turn on some music, or listen to book on tape and get lost for hours on end just driving around in your sandbox, racing, crashing, towing, testing or just exploring. Perhaps most importantly the dev's actually care about this game...One of the drawbacks to buying / playing early access game's is that it is often a gamble. A lot time's the devs become tired with their product and halt devolpment all together, leaving you with a hole in your wallet and a half finished product that'll never be more than that. That however, is not the case here. I owned this game for almost a year now, and throughout that year I have witnessed consistent improvements, patch's and added content. I cannot praise this game enough, I don't have the time to invest thousands of hours playing games like some people do. But I beleive this is my second most played game on steam...Only surpassed by Skyrim, and for the record BeamNG is closing fast on my Skyrim hours. The game has a decent arsenal of vehicles, ranging from your run of the mill work truck (which can modified to suit your taste) to Race cars, to Semi tractor trailers. And the fact, that this game is Steam Workshop compatible mean's that even more vehicle's and track's are just a click away!I'm trying to think of some potential ''con's'' to weigh in with all the ''pro's'' that go with this game. Personally I would like to see even more customization implimented into the game, such as the ability to tune gear ratio's in the transmission and fine tune things like aero dynamics. It would also be nice to be able to add specific upgrade's to your vehicle's engine. As it stand's right now, most vehicle's have Stage 1 Stage 2 and Stage 3 engine tune's and/or intake's that give you three stage's of horsepower/torque. But that's really just cherry picking on my behalf. Let's see what else, For those of you who enjoy playing with others...This is not your game. To my knowledge it currently does not have any form of multiplayer. No internet race's, I heard one time that it has split screen playability, but it's not something I've ever tried to use. I've heard some complaint's that this game only run's good on bad♥♥♥♥♥desktops, which is not completely true, however their's some truth in that statement. My current desktop was top the of line...Eight years ago, which my graphic's turned down a bit I can run most of BeamNG just fine. Howver, until I get a new computer I cannot play on certian level's...Like Moab, it's just to much for my old machine. On the side of sound, it's currently fairly weak. All vehicle's sound the same, a turbo I4 sounds excatly the same as a modified big block V8 in this game, so there isn't a huge veriety in that area, but hopefully that'll be improved upon in future patch's...Personally I just play with the sound off and listen to Reddit horror stories on Youtube while playing. With that said, It's time to tally up the Pro's and Con's.(Pros)AMAZING Physics.Reliable Devs who invest in their product to make consistent improvementsPotential to get lost for hours playing.Immense depth in level's, lot's of exploration to be done.Decent veriety of vehicle's ranging from Pickups to Race cars to Semi's.Supports Steam Workshop, meaning downloadedable vehicle's and tracks are just a click away.(Cons)Taxing to run at high resolution.Needs a little more depth in vehicle tuning.Lame sound effects.In it's current state I give this game a solid (9/10)It was worth every penny I spent on it. I hope you enjoyed this review!

Early Access Review
								BeamNG Drive Early Access. I bought this game a while back and I finally got a Steam key. So here is my review. BeamNG Drive is a driving simulator but not really. I think it is more of a vehicle crash simulator. The crash physics are great and the driving physics are getting there. I really like it. The biggest thing that bugs me is the computer performance. Now, I may not have a gaming PC but I can play other games on medium-high graphics and have no trouble. But on this game, it struggles. A little problem is clipping and fall-through. Clipping is when I crash into another vehicle and the textures clip into each other. Therefore wedging the cars together. Fall-through is my term when a car falls through another car. For example, loading the hatchback into the box truck (of course I remove the doors). I drive the car in and it falls out the bottom of the truck. The bad parts are little enough where the good parts stand out. Overall, a great game. I recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's not a complete game yet, but I recommend it.  The game has evolved since I bought into it's Early Access; so it is not abandonware.The soft-body damage sim system is bloody fantastic and deep.  Not completely realistic, but fantastic.  I'm sure you've seen YouTube videos of BeamNG.drive crashe motages and cars tumbling down mountains getting all smashed up.  The only thing missing is the ability for cars to explode.  They never do.  All they do is sometimes catch fire if you rupture the fuel tank.While this is not yet finished, there is a very large selection of activities (scenarios) you can do.  Checkpoint races, jumping, stunts, destruction missions and other ways to take advantage of the game's unique and extensive soft-body vehicle engine.  There is plenty to do here; it's just not a complete game yet.  The game is also highly moddable so you can create your own scenarios and even 3D props and tracks if you know your way around a 3D modeling program.The game's configuration and control options are DEEP.  It works spectacularly with the Steam Controller once you can figure out how to configure it all.  Steering with the track pad feels great.  The only thing better would be a real steering wheel controller.  Some day!The game's graphics are not state of the art, but they are very crisp.  Let's say crisp but a bit dry.  It would benefit from some ambient occlusion, physically based rendering or other cutting-edge graphic engine elements.  If the game had the graphics engine of Rocket League or Mad Max it would be a very impressive thing indeed.  But what is here is very servicable.  The frame rate is silky smooth on my GTX960.  On the other hand the amount of trees and other foliage around the road is impressive.Now for the negatives.  The game has a beginnings of a campaign.  Appropriately named "Rocky Start."  The actual gameplay is fun.  It has the beginnings of an open-world map with activities you can choose with rewards.  Great stuff.  But the presentation...  It is disjointed.  They chose to use cartoonish, 2D flash-type animations to lead into each part of the campaign.  The art is flatly drawn cartoons.  The people...  I'm sorry.  They look like they tapped someone from DeviantArt.  Crudely drawn cartoons.  The animation looks very low-budget.  This directly contrasts with the actual game world where everything is dimensional, lush, detailed and obviously lovingly crafted.  The 2D art really brings the game down a peg.  And there is other 2D art within another part of the game that is far superior.  They should sack the new artist and use the first one.  Yeah it had the limitations of being 2D but it has style and looks much more professional..  Ugh.. Sorry.. as an artist it's just a pet peeve of mine.  If you aren't going to do it right, don't do it at all.Pros:+ Soft-body physics engine produces AMAZING crashes!+ Skill-based driving and racing.  Watch out for that rock on the side of the narrow road.  It will end your car!+ Variety of activities with a large range of difficulties to choose from+ Nicely crafted (fictional) car models+ Pretty well detailed environments to drive or race through+ Awesome stunts & jumps+ Deep control configurability / Great with Steam Controller+ Free-roaming and wrecking is relaxing fun+ It does not seem like it will become abandonware so farCons:- It's not finished yet (as expected for Early Access).- Graphics engine does not look as good as it could (yet?)- No explosions (yet?)- Ugly, low-budget animated intro segments that are thankfully skippable.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me start off this review by saying I've been following BeamNG since 2012 and bought as soon as the initial release happened in 2013. The dev team has been amazing in supporting and updating the game.Pros:Amazing physics, detailed car design, helpful dev team. The maps are absolutely beautiful also. Cons:The engine is a small bit unoptimized, but the dev team is working on it. Also, sometimes there is a while between updates but the past few have been very timely, and it seems a lot of background work is behind us.All-in-all I recommend this game, though it might not be for everyone. A majority of the game right now is a free-roam crashing simulator, though the devs have added a good many situations and races. Also, this is a state of the art engine. You'll need a fast CPU, and sadly AMD has an architecture stuck in the past. More cores do help, but your AMD will need to be clocked a fair bit higher than usual to keep the FPS other games do. A modern (4+ series) Intel needs about 3.4Ghz to play most of the cars, to keep even the most intensive at 60+fps you'll need 4.0Ghz. Like I said though the engine is being optimized.On the GPU side you can keep solid 60fps on medium with a 280x, and high will keep you mostly 60 but sometimes into the lower 50s. If you max the game with PostFX and reflections it will drag a 280x into the 20fps range and even a 290x has issues keeping up. This hasn't been as much of an issue until this update, so I'll update if it changes again.TL;DR smashy, you need a good computer. I rate 10/10

Early Access Review
								Great game 93/100Pros: - Great, if not the best, physics engine. Destruction is very realistic and awesome. - Driving is realistic and fun. - Okay Modding + Easy Modding. - Not many updates but I do see them adding content or general updates every now and then. - Good offroading. - Fun at any framerate.Cons: - No Multiplayer. - I would like to see more vehicles be added to the game through the developers side, modding is okay but not perfect for this game. They did just release a new offroad vehicle that resembles a Jeep so it's good to know that they are workign on adding more vehicles to the game. - No aircraft or boats. This one I don't mind much at all or really care about but I think it would be great if they added planes, helicopters or boats into the game. - Sounds are, well, not the best. Some vehicles it fits while others it just doesn't. Mods do change some of the sounds but I think that the devs should work and fine tune the sounds a bit more. - Framerate can get low when you have a good amount of vehicles spawned in. For example, if I get 5-10 trucks on one map, I would experience a pretty high fps drop. It's not much of a gripe as it is fun at mostly every framerate, at least above 30. - Not a con but a recommendation, devs, please take out "Free to Play" from the game's tags. ;)System The Game Was Tested On:i5 6600k @3.5GHzGTX 1070 No Overclock16GB Deditated Wam240GB SSD

								This game may not be what you are expecting, especially as of now.The game is meant to be a simulator, and all "game" aspects are secondary to that.That is not to say that it isn't fun, but it might not be to your liking.Being more of a simulator than a game, that also means the driving mechanics may be nothing like what you expect.Ideally you would play with a wheel instead of a gamepad, and would treat the cars much like you'd treat a real one.I wasn't going to review the game until it got to the Race Update at least, but I don't think I'll change my opinions. I've owned this since Christmas '13 and it's mid-August. Development has been pretty consistent and I've seen it grow quite a bit in this short time. The community is still getting off the ground, but the move to Steam should help greatly. I've had quite a lot of fun with this prior to its release on Steam, and I am sure I will in the future.While I will recommend the game, I will do so with the warning that it really isn't for everyone.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me start off this review by saying I've been following BeamNG since 2012 and bought as soon as the initial release happened in 2013. The dev team has been amazing in supporting and updating the game.Pros:Amazing physics, detailed car design, helpful dev team. The maps are absolutely beautiful also. Cons:The engine is a small bit unoptimized, but the dev team is working on it. Also, sometimes there is a while between updates but the past few have been very timely, and it seems a lot of background work is behind us.All-in-all I recommend this game, though it might not be for everyone. A majority of the game right now is a free-roam crashing simulator, though the devs have added a good many situations and races. Also, this is a state of the art engine. You'll need a fast CPU, and sadly AMD has an architecture stuck in the past. More cores do help, but your AMD will need to be clocked a fair bit higher than usual to keep the FPS other games do. A modern (4+ series) Intel needs about 3.4Ghz to play most of the cars, to keep even the most intensive at 60+fps you'll need 4.0Ghz. Like I said though the engine is being optimized.On the GPU side you can keep solid 60fps on medium with a 280x, and high will keep you mostly 60 but sometimes into the lower 50s. If you max the game with PostFX and reflections it will drag a 280x into the 20fps range and even a 290x has issues keeping up. This hasn't been as much of an issue until this update, so I'll update if it changes again.TL;DR smashy, you need a good computer. I rate 10/10

								I have never had more fun crashing cars as this. This game is EA and is updated often. The physics seem very real to me.The cars and the environments could look better. I think it could use some more optimization to run smoother. I'm sure those suggestions and more are in the works. There is a new update available as I write this review. content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game sets off some primitive part of my brain that gives me some sort of morbid curiosity and interest in car crashes. Evolutionarily, it makes no sense; I should be scared of them. You know, winning a Darwin Award is not a prize one would like. Yet, dashcam compilations, Burnout Revenge's Crash mode, and BeamNG.drive are SO DAMN INTERESTING AND FUN. What sets this game apart is its soft body collision physics engine. Which is just a long way of saying that the car physics in this game is really realistic. Let's compare this to Grand Theft Auto where a non-branded Honda Civic can withstand several highway speed crashes much like a M1 Abrams. Sure you lost a door or two and completely destroyed its resale value, but the only thing that matters is that it still runs at a reasonable speed. If you run your car into a wall at highway speeds in this game you'll be assaulted by a hail of windshield bits while you're screaming in agony because your car's A pillar is now embedded into your skull. Hell, if you run into a mildly large rock at a speed suitable for a busy school zone, you'll probably majorly mess up your radiator. This game is just a toy box for me to watch realistic car crashes without the guilt, knowing that no virtual people were hurt in my vehicle destruction. While, sure this game is still in Early Access, it is still worth the money. Surely it's leagues better than some stupid low effort asset-bought Unity game that plagues the Steam store now-a-days.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Okay, after owning and playing this game for the past two years, it's probably time to write a detailed evaluation.I use an Acer Aspire V5 with a crappy A10 CPU and 8650G integrated graphics. I play this game fine sometimes on low graphics, though I am not able to play at full time at all, just due to the specs. You'll get used to the latency and lag. Remember SSAO kills performance, and adjust other settings until desired performance is reachedThe driving feels solid to me. I have had no previous real life driving experience, but this game in my opinion responds better to input than Forza 5, similar to Forza Horizon 3, if you drive properly in this game. Remember to play in a fixed camera view, basically anything but orbit. This is because when the tires start slipping, you can detect and correct the slipping earlier rather than in orbit mode, where the camera is relatively lazy. Remember also specific reactions to drivetypes, like accelerating when an fwd car is in an oversteering state.Remember to use DELICATE TRIGGER CONTROL. The steering is 1:1 with your trigger AT ALL TIMES. It's extremely easy to understeer by turning too quickly, and to overcorrect after initiating oversteer. Also, the skidding sounds seem inconsistient with what's happening, and it's loud basically all the time, which causes you to overreact. Try to trust the visuals more than the sound in this game at it's current state.Once you get used to the controls, it's very satisfying. Just remember to be patient, as the controls require caution and delicate control for maximum enjoyment.

								Great game 93/100Pros: - Great, if not the best, physics engine. Destruction is very realistic and awesome. - Driving is realistic and fun. - Okay Modding + Easy Modding. - Not many updates but I do see them adding content or general updates every now and then. - Good offroading. - Fun at any framerate.Cons: - No Multiplayer. - I would like to see more vehicles be added to the game through the developers side, modding is okay but not perfect for this game. content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								OKAY, rewriting review time. This game has matured so much since I've had it. I've played it daily, I've watched it grow, I've poured many hours into this game and interacted with the community. I taught myself many driving techniques with this game (with some mods so stalling a car is actually possible). This game was the exact game i've wanted since I was a little one playing Flatout 2 on my Xbox. Does it have problems? Absolutely. Do these matter? Absolutely not. I can't get enough of this game. The physics are satisfying, and feel real. I've yet to play a game that can make me cringe when I hit something as small as a trash can at low speed like this one can. The cars are unique and beautiful and every one is labored over to give it the exact characteristics of real life equivalents. They're fun, most imporantly, and I can't get enough of whipping the hatchback (Ibishu Covet) around a corner, or abusing the hell out of the Offraod version of the Pickup (Gavril D-Series). Even the level design shows detail, with maps being unique and having a variety of roads and ways to have fun, be it rallying through country in a small Japanese compact, or tearing up the streets in a souped up American Saloon, or ignoring roads and trails in a jacked-up delivery van. Yes, $24.99 may seem risky for an Early Access game, but these devs absolutely show promise. They constantly update the game, they constantly interact with their community, and I've even had conversations with some of the staff... They're great people, and they love this game like it was their child. They prioritize keeping the game updated, fresh with fun and new stuff, and fixing major problems. I can't tell anyone what to do with their money, but I can more than recommend buying this game to anyone who consults me on it. Please do yourself this favor. Quick notes about this game:-ABSOLUTELY USE A CONTROLLER OR WHEEL, keyboard is still fun but is nowhere near as great as the former two options-Fairly demanding, don't expect to have 10-car derbies with a laptop. Even my i7 4790k and GTX 980 only do 9 cars at once on certain levels before it becomes difficult to play-Bear with the devs, there are problems that pop up... With this in mind, do go to the official BeamNG forums for help, the community and devs always find solutions to these problems

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Beamng.Drive is the most realistic vehicle simulator to date. The crashes are ultra realistic, the damage is ultra realistic, and the physics are ultra realistic. And don't let the graphics card requirements turn you down, because this game really doesn't need that great of a card to run at max graphics settings. I'm running it maxed out at 60+ fps on my Gtx 560 ti 2gb phantom, so no need to buy yourself a Gtx 670 for this game. This game runs great on my pc, but the framerate drops to around 20-40 with 5 cars on screen at the same time, because the game still needs some optimizations. The more cars on screen, the more processor power your pc needs, because each vehicle is extremely highly detailed, and has lots of deformation points and breakables. Ever single vehicle is very advanced and detailed, so you need a very good cpu at the moment if you want to play with 5+ cars on screen. I have an Intel core I5-3470 3.20GHz quad core cpu, and it can handle around 5 cars on screen at once with playable framerates. They said they are gonna improve framerates later on. They want to make 7 cars on screen at once run smoothly on a mid range processor, so the cpu requirements will get lower with the updates. Another awesome thing about this game is all the maps and cars you can download for free. You can also make maps and vehicles and upload them to beamng's website for others to download. It's a lot of fun, and you can do anything vehicle related you've always wanted to do with no limitations! The game's map editor is also very easy to use once you get used to it. You can create cutom objects and buildings for the map editor too by using other programs like sketchup and importing your creations to beamng's editor. It is fairly simple and easy to do. Just watch a tutorial video or two, and you can make maps with ease. Sorry for the long post, I just needed to tell you if you feel the game lacks content, you can create your own content or download content for it that other people created. The game also gets updates, since it's still work in progress, so even if you don't download or make content for the game, you will still have a great time, although I reccomend downloading others's creations and making your own stuff for the game, because it makes the game more fun. This game is very realistic and very fun at the same time. Your car can even run out of fuel, but don't worry about filling up every 2 minutes, because it takes as long as in real life for the cars in this game to run out of fuel. Besides, you'll probably wreck the car before you can get a chance to run out of fuel, since one hard crash can pretty much total your vehicle. This game is a lot of fun, and very realistic at the same time. 10 out of 10. The perfect vehicle simulator.

								It's been almost a year since I wrote my first review for this game, and I feel it deserves an updated review.This is a good game. The crashes are fantastic to watch, and the physics are great. But this game does have a couple problems and improvements that could be made.Pros:-Looks good.-Runs fairly well, but isn't the best at optimization.-Physics are fun.-Crashes are fantastic.-Has a photo mode.-Lots of different scenarios and environments.-Good selection of props and vehicles, it even has a cannon.-Has a practice track.Neutral:-Physics are still a little strange, but has improved a bunch.-Looking/changing your key bindings can be a little confusing.-Menu is still confusing. Cons:-Still has bugs, including the occasional crash.-Controls are still wonky and aren't explained very well.Tl;dr, if you want a crashing/driving simulator, then this is the way to go. But only buy if you have a decently powerful machine and don't mind the strange physics and controls.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								BeamNG.drive is a physics simulation from some of the same people that brought you Rigs of Rods[www.rigsofrods.com] and some of its top quality mods. When comparing the two, it is evident that lots of lessons have been learnt and that each developer has improved greatly in their respective field, resulting in state of the art physics that simulate every single part of a vehicle/object with almost true to life accuracy (with accuracy and efficiency being improved as development goes on), near perfectly modelled fictional vehicles that each represent a certain type of vehicle, resulting in a diverse, albeit small selection (current vehicle list, [wiki.beamng.com] in-dev, concept vehicles list[wiki.beamng.com]) , and fantastic locations[wiki.beamng.com] that push the graphics engine, Torque3D[www.garagegames.com] to its limits. Currently, the Small Island map is my personal favourite mainly due to the recent overhaul that added so many little details. I hope Dry Rock is also updated in a similar fashion.In terms of gameplay, it is currently just a sandbox, but a planned update will bring timed races (no advanced AI YET) and online leaderboards to the table as the first step in the direction of given gameplay, but I still think the sandbox will be where the majority of the entertainment is.The game is very moddable, all sorts of vehicles can be added, including helicopters and planes, levels can be created in the in-game level editor, and LUA files that make up quite a lot of the code can be freely edited to tailor your experience to your liking or even add features. A feature that I quite like that has been created by the community with LUA scripting has been changing the engine sound depending on the vehicle that is being used. Mods should only be downloaded from the official forum's showroom and downloading from anywhere else will either leave you with some kind of malware or very disappointed.The current sound system is a placeholder to avoid people moaning about "sound not working" really, with a single engine, skid, and crash sound making up the entirety of the vehicle's vocabulary (can be modded though) and a few ambient background tracks. This will be completely redone eventually.The vehicle's handling characteristics can be quirky at times with some seemingly random veering at very high speeds and vehicles losing friction too easily, but the physics will be continuously improved and tweaked to ensure maximum authenticity. I can see this rivalling high profile racing simulators in the future.The game needs a fairly high end CPU (or more specifically, a CPU with fairly powerful cores) in order to run the physics smoothly. My i5 3570k can run 4 detailed vehicles smoothly, but those with certain AMD CPUs may struggle. Even though they have lots of cores, each core is quite weak. To run the game at max graphical settings, a fairly powerful GPU will also be required, but most semi-recent mid range video cards should be able to run it with lower settings fine. The tech demo will be updated soon so I suggest going to beamng.com and trying it out before purchasing.I've probably sunk hundreds of hours into it so it's safe to say that I've probably got my money's worth.I think that is all I currently have to say, but I'll probably remember something else in 5 minutes.TL;DR:  Physics, mods, don't complain if your ZX Spectrum doesn't run it at 120 fps etc.

Posted: April 15, 2016
Early Access Review
Love the game.It's a great game to play if you just want to sit back, relax, fool around on facebook and listen to music. If you have been dreaming of a game with realistic crash damage, this is absolutely the game for you. The soft body physics are pretty well flawless unless you download a ported community created car. Most community created cars are done well though and are very fun to play with in this smash em' up car simulator. One thing I'm sad about is that there is no community workshop for this game for user created cars and maps so you have to download from their  website [www.beamng.com]. Even still, installation of community creations is very simple; just a drag and drop of a folder. There are some missions for you to play where you can drive through checkpoints and do jumps and all, but besides that, there is no objective other than what you make up. You can test your car's durability as hard as you want with this game. It gives you complete freedom of how to smash your car, always with a satisfying result and that is why recommend this game.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								8/13/2014got my alpha code in email because i had played it a while ago. last time i had played it, it was very similar, but a lot more buggy and had less content. that was probably 1-3 years ago, i cant remember. but i had only played it for an hour and got fed up with it before uninstalling it because it was so ♥♥♥♥♥♥.NOW, it installs over steam, has longish loading times (who cares though), the controls are kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ for m+k but work if you're patient and learn to tap and feather the keys you can deal with it, and the graphics (artstyle) are fairly nice, but a little lacking contrast in the colors.The game runs fairly well, considering how much♥♥♥♥♥♥is actually being drawn on screen and how the devs implemented it (see: placing a bunch of objects on screen by hand). Which means: its really nice to explore and see the sights, but you need a powerful computer to do it. I'm running a 768mb 460gtx and a first gen i7. With all graphics up to high (except the garrys mod-esqe post processing) I get about 15fps while completely stationary in a forrest. with most things on lowest or low (lowest threshold until the game looks like♥♥♥♥♥♥due to flat meshes and NO shading) I can get up to about 55fps.there's a lot of pop-in for random tree areas and buildings, which isnt really a big deal but worth noting.the car handling itself is fairly difficult, because at low speeds the cars handle alright but once you speed up, the fps chugs randomly, the cars feel like they're on ice and makes crashes/flips inevitable. It almost feels like they're trying to make you crash. This is neat for showing off your crash mechanics (which i admit are incredible, i ripped out a part of my steering on one side because i high centered over a large rock and couldnt control that wheel much) you can ctrl+r to reload your vehicle and drop five feet away, but the location drifts a little to one direction each time and you can easily be stuck in a load-loop into a wall or trees or some other obsticle with no way out except to keep hitting reload unti you come out the other side. Pretty annoying, yet..... somehow satisfying when you're free.If I get a wheel or controller, a more powerful computer, and they keep adding content and fixing bugs, I'd say this game could be the driving sandbox (gta style raging/romping) equivalent of a walking-sim type game. There are jumps, trails, roads all around the island in grand touring style, big meadows, swamps, ponds, beaches, abandoned buildings a la ken block, and lots of things to smash your car on and have to reset. It would make a VERY nice exploration/relaxing/personal satisfaction driving sim with a high potential of adventure. My biggest desires for adds/fixes for this game are:1) customizable suspension and drivetrain settings to tweak2) them to keep adding more content because I like the style they're doing it in (the offroad 4x4 stuff is REALLY nice)3) optimizations ZOMG<---4) better color palette (its not bad, just leaves something to be desired and feels washed out when out in the open)6) more cars!!!7) the handling to not be so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (maybe this is just because im trying to control a sim driving game with a keyboard)8) better follow-view camera9) some extra motivation for playing it besides just screwing around (missions, characters, story, multiplayer, rpg, unlocking more content/vehicles/zones/parts/things, races, timetrials)10) the ability to get out of the car and do other things, gta style)Right now, the game isnt worth much if you dont like driving around irl or in gta games. I dont know much about the pacing of the dev, but Im going to go ahead and say they're slow as ♥♥♥♥. In a few years, maybe this game will be really cool. But, until then, its very much in alpha and has been for a long time. If this is your thing, cool, if you can't entertain yourself by driving around and exploring in a very buggy game, steer clear of this one for now.sound: 6/10 (nice directionality, but all cars sound the same and stuff isnt very dynamic. great ambience. not too buggy.)graphics: 7.5/10 (if you could get it all to run at a decent fps with no pop-in or stuttering, it would be VERY nice.)menus: 5/10 (lots of options, yet somehow still lacking options. average to bad organization. very ♥♥♥♥♥♥ loading times.)art: 7/10 (cool, sterile, matrix like maps. really cool idea of loading up a world feel. surprisingly immersive. "cozy".)playability: 4/10 (sub average. frustrating experience driving around on the roads, but very pleasurable 4x4 experiences.)value: 6/10 (the ability to drop in with no strings is a double edged sword. easy to get into, easy to get out of once it crashes.)overall: 6/10 (its a slightly above average early access game with a lot of potential. whether or not the devs will realize their own potential is a whole different story. I'm going to learn towards "yes, but not in any near time in the future if ever")

								BeamNG game should definitely be in the steam library of those who love cars as much as they love trashing them. If you wish to explore, you can choose out of 10 available levels to play in Free Roam. More content is being added into the game roughly around each month (depends on content). With this game you will never get tired of watching the car of your choice crash into a wall at 60 mp/h in slow-motion.
