content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								8/13/2014got my alpha code in email because i had played it a while ago. last time i had played it, it was very similar, but a lot more buggy and had less content. that was probably 1-3 years ago, i cant remember. but i had only played it for an hour and got fed up with it before uninstalling it because it was so ♥♥♥♥♥♥.NOW, it installs over steam, has longish loading times (who cares though), the controls are kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ for m+k but work if you're patient and learn to tap and feather the keys you can deal with it, and the graphics (artstyle) are fairly nice, but a little lacking contrast in the colors.The game runs fairly well, considering how much♥♥♥♥♥♥is actually being drawn on screen and how the devs implemented it (see: placing a bunch of objects on screen by hand). Which means: its really nice to explore and see the sights, but you need a powerful computer to do it. I'm running a 768mb 460gtx and a first gen i7. With all graphics up to high (except the garrys mod-esqe post processing) I get about 15fps while completely stationary in a forrest. with most things on lowest or low (lowest threshold until the game looks like♥♥♥♥♥♥due to flat meshes and NO shading) I can get up to about 55fps.there's a lot of pop-in for random tree areas and buildings, which isnt really a big deal but worth noting.the car handling itself is fairly difficult, because at low speeds the cars handle alright but once you speed up, the fps chugs randomly, the cars feel like they're on ice and makes crashes/flips inevitable. It almost feels like they're trying to make you crash. This is neat for showing off your crash mechanics (which i admit are incredible, i ripped out a part of my steering on one side because i high centered over a large rock and couldnt control that wheel much) you can ctrl+r to reload your vehicle and drop five feet away, but the location drifts a little to one direction each time and you can easily be stuck in a load-loop into a wall or trees or some other obsticle with no way out except to keep hitting reload unti you come out the other side. Pretty annoying, yet..... somehow satisfying when you're free.If I get a wheel or controller, a more powerful computer, and they keep adding content and fixing bugs, I'd say this game could be the driving sandbox (gta style raging/romping) equivalent of a walking-sim type game. There are jumps, trails, roads all around the island in grand touring style, big meadows, swamps, ponds, beaches, abandoned buildings a la ken block, and lots of things to smash your car on and have to reset. It would make a VERY nice exploration/relaxing/personal satisfaction driving sim with a high potential of adventure. My biggest desires for adds/fixes for this game are:1) customizable suspension and drivetrain settings to tweak2) them to keep adding more content because I like the style they're doing it in (the offroad 4x4 stuff is REALLY nice)3) optimizations ZOMG<---4) better color palette (its not bad, just leaves something to be desired and feels washed out when out in the open)6) more cars!!!7) the handling to not be so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (maybe this is just because im trying to control a sim driving game with a keyboard)8) better follow-view camera9) some extra motivation for playing it besides just screwing around (missions, characters, story, multiplayer, rpg, unlocking more content/vehicles/zones/parts/things, races, timetrials)10) the ability to get out of the car and do other things, gta style)Right now, the game isnt worth much if you dont like driving around irl or in gta games. I dont know much about the pacing of the dev, but Im going to go ahead and say they're slow as ♥♥♥♥. In a few years, maybe this game will be really cool. But, until then, its very much in alpha and has been for a long time. If this is your thing, cool, if you can't entertain yourself by driving around and exploring in a very buggy game, steer clear of this one for now.sound: 6/10 (nice directionality, but all cars sound the same and stuff isnt very dynamic. great ambience. not too buggy.)graphics: 7.5/10 (if you could get it all to run at a decent fps with no pop-in or stuttering, it would be VERY nice.)menus: 5/10 (lots of options, yet somehow still lacking options. average to bad organization. very ♥♥♥♥♥♥ loading times.)art: 7/10 (cool, sterile, matrix like maps. really cool idea of loading up a world feel. surprisingly immersive. "cozy".)playability: 4/10 (sub average. frustrating experience driving around on the roads, but very pleasurable 4x4 experiences.)value: 6/10 (the ability to drop in with no strings is a double edged sword. easy to get into, easy to get out of once it crashes.)overall: 6/10 (its a slightly above average early access game with a lot of potential. whether or not the devs will realize their own potential is a whole different story. I'm going to learn towards "yes, but not in any near time in the future if ever")

Love the game.It's a great game to play if you just want to sit back, relax, fool around on facebook and listen to music. If you have been dreaming of a game with realistic crash damage, this is absolutely the game for you. The soft body physics are pretty well flawless unless you download a ported community created car. Most community created cars are done well though and are very fun to play with in this smash em' up car simulator. One thing I'm sad about is that there is no community workshop for this game for user created cars and maps so you have to download from their  website [www.beamng.com]. Even still, installation of community creations is very simple; just a drag and drop of a folder. There are some missions for you to play where you can drive through checkpoints and do jumps and all, but besides that, there is no objective other than what you make up. You can test your car's durability as hard as you want with this game. It gives you complete freedom of how to smash your car, always with a satisfying result and that is why recommend this game.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game horrifies me, utterly and terribly. I'm on the last of a fifteen checkpoint trial. I slide around a corner doing twenty-five. My eyes widen in terror when I see a tree clip my back wheel, bending it all to hell and making the race impossible to finish. *presses "R" to restart for the tenth time*Let me just say, this game is hard. Your car will feel slow and clunky and will squash like a bug at seemingly stupid slow speeds. It is just about as realistic in that regard as it gets. Like any racing game, there are fast and slow cars. Except they all break equally as easy, so don't think going faster is always better.And as for so many people saying the cars feel like they're on ice, ignore them. If you've ever driven on solid ice, you would know that you can't get going more than a few miles an hour in a decent turn before you're going sideways. A car is held in place by four little patches of rubber each about the size of your hand. Once you break sliding friction, you're boned.Also, for anyone turned off by the fact that this is a "crashing simulator," I would also disagree. The fun is in the trials. The launching your car off a four story cube in the test world gets boring after a while. There are something like 15 ish trials right now that range from small circuits to long rallies to silly stuff like seeing if you can jump four ramps in a row or make your way down a six-hundred foot cliff. There will be a campaign mode integrated eventually.The game encourages smart driving (knowing the limits of your car, how fast you need to enter turns, when to accelerate and when to brake). You don't need a steering wheel or pedals, but I'm sure they'd be fun.The only issue I have with the game is its checkpoint system. First of all, they're huge and kinda ugly. Secondly, if you try to switch out your vehicle with another mid-race, it screws everything up.I don't mind this one, but the sound is kinda awful. Engines sounds are cool, crashes are just okay, but the tire squeeling is horrible.This game is fun for what it is already, and definitely worth the money. The devs do decent sized updates about every month now and release bug fixes several times a month to deal with whatever they broke in the patches and/or fix other small issues.I never write reviews, but I figured this would be the one. Just goes to show how great I think this game is.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I recommend this game to anyone who is in search of a crash simulator, a driving simulator, a game with realistic In-Depth car customisation or just a way to pass some time if you dont want to bother loading into any other game.So far I have played almost 80 hours of this game, which is a fairly high amount for me and actually more than I have played GTA V. I have installed quite a few mods and lokked deep into the vehicle customization.Just a few things you can do in the game:-Simulate crashes with (on my PC) up to six vehicles (which can have a rudimentary AI)-Just drive around and relax-Create your very own dream vehicle from models roughly resembling real life cars-Race around various tracks included in some of the maps-Finetune your suspension in terms of ride height, spring stiffness, track width and more-Install dozens of mods, some of them with incredibly high quality-explore the detailed maps, find all the secret passages- ... and quite a lot more!As far as I can tell, the game runs very smoothly until you spawn to many cars (6 on my PC), it looks great even on lower graphical settings and has a FoV-Slider so TotalBiscuit will be happy. Extremely high velocity/force impacts don't look that great, but are still a accurate depiction of what would happen to a similar car (despite some parts clipping through others bended textures/Jbeams etc...) Aside from that crashes in this game are almost worthy of next generation car testing. E.g. brake thermals and cooling liquids and other stuff gets simulated.Stuff you should know:Though it's possible to play this game with a keyboard you will have a hard time controlling especially the stronger/older car variants. This is because a keyboard limits you to full throttle, none at all and hard braking. The best option would be a steering wheel,but a contoller also works just fine. The game has force feedback compatibility in general, however this doesn't apply to my ancient  SpeedLink wheel.There is a experimental replay feature, but it's still a buggy mess. I guess it will be fixed very soon, look out for that.Which brings me to my next point: The game gets updated regularly (a major content patch comes out every 1/2 months, of high quality, with bugfixes, optimisations and like I said, content). BeamNG also has a very nice and helpful community.What I don't like as of now:-The sounds (which have been described as placeholders by the devs) are plain horrible, but they said that they hired a     sound effects guy in the last devblog.-The particles are not all that detailed and plenty compared to real car crashes-The game tends to bug out sometimes, nothing major, but it's there and its annoying

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game horrifies me, utterly and terribly. I'm on the last of a fifteen checkpoint trial. I slide around a corner doing twenty-five. My eyes widen in terror when I see a tree clip my back wheel, bending it all to hell and making the race impossible to finish. *presses "R" to restart for the tenth time*Let me just say, this game is hard. Your car will feel slow and clunky and will squash like a bug at seemingly stupid slow speeds. It is just about as realistic in that regard as it gets. Like any racing game, there are fast and slow cars. Except they all break equally as easy, so don't think going faster is always better.And as for so many people saying the cars feel like they're on ice, ignore them. If you've ever driven on solid ice, you would know that you can't get going more than a few miles an hour in a decent turn before you're going sideways. A car is held in place by four little patches of rubber each about the size of your hand. Once you break sliding friction, you're boned.Also, for anyone turned off by the fact that this is a "crashing simulator," I would also disagree. The fun is in the trials. The launching your car off a four story cube in the test world gets boring after a while. There are something like 15 ish trials right now that range from small circuits to long rallies to silly stuff like seeing if you can jump four ramps in a row or make your way down a six-hundred foot cliff. There will be a campaign mode integrated eventually.The game encourages smart driving (knowing the limits of your car, how fast you need to enter turns, when to accelerate and when to brake). You don't need a steering wheel or pedals, but I'm sure they'd be fun.The only issue I have with the game is its checkpoint system. First of all, they're huge and kinda ugly. Secondly, if you try to switch out your vehicle with another mid-race, it screws everything up.I don't mind this one, but the sound is kinda awful. Engines sounds are cool, crashes are just okay, but the tire squeeling is horrible.This game is fun for what it is already, and definitely worth the money. The devs do decent sized updates about every month now and release bug fixes several times a month to deal with whatever they broke in the patches and/or fix other small issues.I never write reviews, but I figured this would be the one. Just goes to show how great I think this game is.

Early Access Review
								My BeamNG.drive experience:


YouTube™ Video: BeamNG crash compilation 

			Views: 197		

			My BeamNG.drive experience		

Not the best quality but it gives you an idea.BeamNG.drive really is a nice game. I personally adore sandboxes, just because you can do whatever you want. The fact that you can download mods makes it even better, you are actually encouraged to install mods and expand the possibilities to the max. I don't have a drivers license, so I can't say much about how the verhicles handle in comparison with real ones, however, I know enough about physics to say that it is pretty damn good. For example, when you brake slowly without slipping instead of completely burning your tires, you will actually brake faster because the braking force is higher. When you accelerate when your vehicle is flying through the air, you won't see your actual speed because your tires don't touch the ground. Next to all those details you can also place small apps on the screen that show engine info, like the force from the engine itself, the force from the tires, windspeed, weight, G-force, etc. etc. The game does contain some minor bugs, but because it is still an early access game, I don't mind.Overall: 7,5/10

Posted: September 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I recommend this game to anyone who is in search of a crash simulator, a driving simulator, a game with realistic In-Depth car customisation or just a way to pass some time if you dont want to bother loading into any other game.So far I have played almost 80 hours of this game, which is a fairly high amount for me and actually more than I have played GTA V. I have installed quite a few mods and lokked deep into the vehicle customization.Just a few things you can do in the game:-Simulate crashes with (on my PC) up to six vehicles (which can have a rudimentary AI)-Just drive around and relax-Create your very own dream vehicle from models roughly resembling real life cars-Race around various tracks included in some of the maps-Finetune your suspension in terms of ride height, spring stiffness, track width and more-Install dozens of mods, some of them with incredibly high quality-explore the detailed maps, find all the secret passages- ... and quite a lot more!As far as I can tell, the game runs very smoothly until you spawn to many cars (6 on my PC), it looks great even on lower graphical settings and has a FoV-Slider so TotalBiscuit will be happy. Extremely high velocity/force impacts don't look that great, but are still a accurate depiction of what would happen to a similar car (despite some parts clipping through others bended textures/Jbeams etc...) Aside from that crashes in this game are almost worthy of next generation car testing. E.g. brake thermals and cooling liquids and other stuff gets simulated.Stuff you should know:Though it's possible to play this game with a keyboard you will have a hard time controlling especially the stronger/older car variants. This is because a keyboard limits you to full throttle, none at all and hard braking. The best option would be a steering wheel,but a contoller also works just fine. The game has force feedback compatibility in general, however this doesn't apply to my ancient  SpeedLink wheel.There is a experimental replay feature, but it's still a buggy mess. I guess it will be fixed very soon, look out for that.Which brings me to my next point: The game gets updated regularly (a major content patch comes out every 1/2 months, of high quality, with bugfixes, optimisations and like I said, content). BeamNG also has a very nice and helpful community.What I don't like as of now:-The sounds (which have been described as placeholders by the devs) are plain horrible, but they said that they hired a     sound effects guy in the last devblog.-The particles are not all that detailed and plenty compared to real car crashes-The game tends to bug out sometimes, nothing major, but it's there and its annoying

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								"Best Crash Test Game Out There!" -SilveringotThis game has the best softbody physics that I have ever seen! much better then most other similar games, But crashing cars isn't all of the fun. You can drive around at a nice speed on a nice island! or do some offroading on a mountain road or even do some racing... in a pickup truck! if your in that sort of stuff. You can and probably will drive a bare chassis! YES! you can do that no body panels no body! just a metal chassis with wheels of course. But when you strip a car down to its bare parts you can actually see the detail! I saw a lot of parts that I've seen before! Also the interior... You will feel like driving a real Car/SUV/thing! You got working head and taillights (with brights!) you have turn singles and hazards, you can see the pedals on the floor corrospond with your actions! the only thing you don't have is a horn.But now for the cons...All the Cars/Trucks/SUVS/things! have the same engine noise! (Except the Ibishu Covet, Which has a peppy I-4) Oh also the bugs/crash issues (BUT most of the time these are fixed in the same month.)NOTE: I have played this game for almost a 2 3/4 years, I got this game before it came onto steam. (P.S NOTE: This review was edited because most of the negetive stuff I had in this review was patched in game!)
